◆ read_met_ml2pl()

void read_met_ml2pl ( const ctl_t *  ctl,
const met_t *  met,
float  var[EX][EY][EP],
const char *  varname 
)

Interpolates meteorological data to specified pressure levels.

This function interpolates meteorological data from model levels to pressure levels. The interpolation is performed in parallel over the spatial grid defined in the meteorological data structure.

Parameters
[in]ctlA pointer to a control structure containing the number of pressure levels (met_np) and the pressure levels themselves (met_p).
[in]metA pointer to a meteorological data structure containing the grid dimensions (nx, ny) and the pressure profile (pl).
[in,out]varA 3D array containing the meteorological variable to be interpolated. On output, this array will contain the interpolated values at the specified pressure levels.
[in]varnameA string representing the name of the meteorological variable being interpolated.

This function performs the following steps:

  • Sets a timer for the operation.
  • Logs the start of the interpolation process with the variable name.
  • Loops over the spatial columns (grid points).
  • For each column, copies the pressure profile.
  • Interpolates the meteorological variable to the specified pressure levels.
  • Copies the interpolated data back into the var array.
Note
The interpolation is performed in parallel using OpenMP.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 9710 of file mptrac.c.

9714 {
9715
9716 double aux[EP], p[EP];
9717
9718 /* Set timer... */
9719 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_ML2PL", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
9720 LOG(2, "Interpolate meteo data to pressure levels: %s", varname);
9721
9722 /* Loop over columns... */
9723#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) private(aux,p) collapse(2)
9724 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
9725 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
9726
9727 /* Copy pressure profile... */
9728 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip++)
9729 p[ip] = met->pl[ix][iy][ip];
9730
9731 /* Interpolate... */
9732 for (int ip = 0; ip < ctl->met_np; ip++) {
9733 double pt = ctl->met_p[ip];
9734 if ((pt > p[0] && p[0] > p[1]) || (pt < p[0] && p[0] < p[1]))
9735 pt = p[0];
9736 else if ((pt > p[met->np - 1] && p[1] > p[0])
9737 || (pt < p[met->np - 1] && p[1] < p[0]))
9738 pt = p[met->np - 1];
9739 const int ip2 = locate_irr(p, met->np, pt);
9740 aux[ip] = LIN(p[ip2], var[ix][iy][ip2],
9741 p[ip2 + 1], var[ix][iy][ip2 + 1], pt);
9742 }
9743
9744 /* Copy data... */
9745 for (int ip = 0; ip < ctl->met_np; ip++)
9746 var[ix][iy][ip] = (float) aux[ip];
9747 }
9748}
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ read_met_monotonize()

void read_met_monotonize ( const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met 
)

Makes zeta and pressure profiles monotone.

This function ensures that zeta and pressure profiles are monotone increasing and decreasing with altitude. It iterates over each grid point and each level to identify inversions and linearly interpolate between them to maintain monotonicity. The interpolation is performed for both zeta and pressure profiles.

Parameters
ctlA pointer to a control parameter structure.
metA pointer to a structure containing meteorological data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets up a timer to monitor the processing time.
  • Iterates over each grid point in parallel using OpenMP.
  • Identifies inversions in both zeta and pressure profiles and interpolates linearly between them to make the profiles monotone increasing.
Note
This function is crucial for maintaining the physical consistency of meteorological profiles, ensuring accurate atmospheric simulations.
Author
Jan Clemens

Definition at line 9752 of file mptrac.c.

9754 {
9755
9756 /* Check parameters... */
9757 if (ctl->advect_vert_coord != 1)
9758 return;
9759
9760 /* Set timer... */
9761 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_MONOTONIZE", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
9762 LOG(2, "Make zeta profiles monotone...");
9763
9764 /* Create monotone zeta profiles... */
9765#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
9766 for (int i = 0; i < met->nx; i++)
9767 for (int j = 0; j < met->ny; j++) {
9768 int k = 1;
9769
9770 while (k < met->npl) { /* Check if there is an inversion at level k... */
9771 if ((met->zetal[i][j][k - 1] >= met->zetal[i][j][k])) {
9772 /* Find the upper level k+l over the inversion... */
9773 int l = 0;
9774 do {
9775 l++;
9776 }
9777 while ((met->zetal[i][j][k - 1] >=
9778 met->zetal[i][j][k + l]) & (k + l < met->npl));
9779
9780 /* Interpolate linear between the top and bottom
9781 of the inversion... */
9782 float s =
9783 (float) (met->zetal[i][j][k + l] - met->zetal[i][j][k - 1])
9784 / (float) (met->hybrid[k + l] - met->hybrid[k - 1]);
9785
9786 for (int m = k; m < k + l; m++) {
9787 float d = (float) (met->hybrid[m] - met->hybrid[k - 1]);
9788 met->zetal[i][j][m] = s * d + met->zetal[i][j][k - 1];
9789 }
9790
9791 /* Search for more inversions above the last inversion ... */
9792 k = k + l;
9793 } else {
9794 k++;
9795 }
9796 }
9797 }
9798
9799 /* Create monotone pressure profiles... */
9800#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
9801 for (int i = 0; i < met->nx; i++)
9802 for (int j = 0; j < met->ny; j++) {
9803 int k = 1;
9804
9805 while (k < met->npl) { /* Check if there is an inversion at level k... */
9806 if ((met->pl[i][j][k - 1] <= met->pl[i][j][k])) {
9807
9808 /* Find the upper level k+l over the inversion... */
9809 int l = 0;
9810 do {
9811 l++;
9812 }
9813 while ((met->pl[i][j][k - 1] <= met->pl[i][j][k + l]) & (k + l <
9814 met->npl));
9815
9816 /* Interpolate linear between the top and bottom
9817 of the inversion... */
9818 float s = (float) (met->pl[i][j][k + l] - met->pl[i][j][k - 1])
9819 / (float) (met->hybrid[k + l] - met->hybrid[k - 1]);
9820
9821 for (int m = k; m < k + l; m++) {
9822 float d = (float) (met->hybrid[m] - met->hybrid[k - 1]);
9823 met->pl[i][j][m] = s * d + met->pl[i][j][k - 1];
9824 }
9825
9826 /* Search for more inversions above the last inversion ... */
9827 k += l;
9828 } else {
9829 k++;
9830 }
9831 }
9832 }
9833}

◆ read_met_nc()

int read_met_nc ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met,
dd_t *  dd 
)

Reads meteorological data from a NetCDF file and processes it.

This function reads meteorological data from a NetCDF file specified by the filename parameter, using the NetCDF library. It reads grid, surface, and vertical level data, processes the data (including extrapolation, boundary conditions, and downsampling), and calculates various derived meteorological fields such as geopotential heights, potential vorticity, cloud properties, and convective available potential energy (CAPE).

Parameters
filenameA constant character pointer representing the name of the NetCDF file to read the meteorological data from.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure, which contains control parameters for reading and processing the meteorological data.
metA pointer to a met_t structure that will store the meteorological data read and processed from the NetCDF file.
Returns
Returns 1 on success, or 0 if the file cannot be opened.
Note
  • The function opens the NetCDF file in read-only mode using nc_open and handles any errors during the file opening process.
  • The function reads grid data, vertical level data, and surface data from the file, and processes the data to calculate additional meteorological parameters.
  • If the file cannot be opened, the function logs a warning and returns 0.
  • It is important to ensure that the NetCDF file contains the expected structure for meteorological data (grid, levels, surface data).
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 9837 of file mptrac.c.

9850 &ncid))

9854 WARN("Cannot open file!");
9855 return 0;

9867
9868 /* Close file... */
9869 NC(nc_close(ncid));
9870
9871 /* Return success... */
9872 return 1;
9873}

read_met_nc_grid
void read_met_nc_grid(const char *filename, const int ncid, const ctl_t *ctl, met_t *met, dd_t *dd)
Reads meteorological grid data from NetCDF files with domain decomposition.
Definition: mptrac.c:8263
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ read_met_nc_grid_dd_naive()

void read_met_nc_grid_dd_naive ( dd_t *  dd,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met,
const int  ncid 
)

Read meteorological grid data from a NetCDF file and set up subdomain decomposition with halos.

This function initializes the distributed grid decomposition for meteorological data stored in a NetCDF file. It queries global grid dimensions (longitude, latitude), determines the local subdomain size for each MPI rank, and sets up hyperslabs for reading data in parallel. It also constructs halo regions for subdomain boundaries, ensuring periodic wrap-around in the zonal direction when applicable.

The function adjusts subdomain sizes at the right and bottom edges of the global grid to exactly fit the full domain. It then updates the met_t structure with the local longitude and latitude arrays for the subdomain including halos, and stores decomposition metadata in the dd_t structure.

Parameters
[out]ddPointer to a dd_t structure. On output, it contains:
  • MPI rank and size
  • subdomain start indices and counts
  • halo start indices and counts
  • subdomain longitude and latitude ranges
  • halo offsets
[in]ctlPointer to a ctl_t structure containing decomposition parameters:
  • ctl->dd_subdomains_zonal
  • ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional
  • ctl->dd_halos_size
[out]metPointer to a met_t structure. On output, it contains:
  • subdomain grid dimensions (nx, ny, np)
  • longitude and latitude arrays restricted to the subdomain including halos.
[in]ncidNetCDF file ID obtained from a call to nc_open.
Note
  • Requires MPI if compiled with -DMPI.
  • Assumes latitude is ordered from 90 to -90 (descending). A warning is issued if latitude range is positive.
  • Allocates and frees temporary arrays for global longitude and latitude.
  • Halo setup ensures overlap with neighboring subdomains, and handles wrap-around at the left and right boundaries.
  • For periodic grids, the longitude range is assumed to be 360°.
Author
Jan Clemens

Definition at line 9877 of file mptrac.c.

9881 {
9882
9883 int varid;
9884
9885 /* Get the MPI information... */
9886#ifdef MPI
9887 MPI_Comm_rank(MPI_COMM_WORLD, &dd->rank);
9888 MPI_Comm_size(MPI_COMM_WORLD, &dd->size);
9889#endif
9890
9891 int help_nx_glob;
9892 int help_ny_glob;
9893
9894 /* Get grid dimensions... */
9895 NC_INQ_DIM("lon", &help_nx_glob, 0, 0, 0);
9896 LOG(2, "Number of longitudes: %d", help_nx_glob);
9897 met->nx = (int) floor(help_nx_glob / ctl->dd_subdomains_zonal);
9898
9899 NC_INQ_DIM("lat", &help_ny_glob, 0, 0, 0);
9900 LOG(2, "Number of latitudes: %d", help_ny_glob);
9901 met->ny = (int) floor(help_ny_glob / ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional);
9902
9903 double *help_lon_glob;
9904 double *help_lat_glob;
9905 ALLOC(help_lon_glob, double,
9906 help_nx_glob);
9907 ALLOC(help_lat_glob, double,
9908 help_ny_glob);
9909
9910 /* Read global longitudes and latitudes... */
9911 NC_GET_DOUBLE("lon", help_lon_glob, 1);
9912 LOG(2, "Longitudes: %g, %g ... %g deg",
9913 help_lon_glob[0], help_lon_glob[1], help_lon_glob[help_nx_glob - 1]);
9914 NC_GET_DOUBLE("lat", help_lat_glob, 1);
9915 LOG(2, "Latitudes: %g, %g ... %g deg",
9916 help_lat_glob[0], help_lat_glob[1], help_lat_glob[help_ny_glob - 1]);
9917
9918 /* Determine hyperslabs for reading the data in parallel... */
9919
9920 /* Check for edge cases... */
9921 int left = (dd->rank <= ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional - 1);
9922 int right = (dd->rank >= dd->size - ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional);
9923 int top = (dd->rank % ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional == 0);
9924 int bottom =
9925 (dd->rank % ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional ==
9926 ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional - 1);
9927
9928 /* Set the hyperslab for the subdomain... */
9929 dd->subdomain_start[0] = 0;
9930 dd->subdomain_start[1] = 0;
9931 dd->subdomain_start[2] =
9932 (size_t) ((dd->rank % ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional) * met->ny);
9933 dd->subdomain_start[3] =
9934 (size_t) (floor(dd->rank / ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional) * met->nx);
9935
9936 /* Extend subdomains at the right and bottom to fit the full domain. */
9937 if (right) {
9938 int gap = help_nx_glob - ctl->dd_subdomains_zonal * met->nx;
9939 if (gap > 0) {
9940 met->nx = met->nx + gap;
9941 WARN("Extended subdomains at the right to fit to full domain.");
9942 }
9943 }
9944 if (bottom) {
9945 int gap = help_ny_glob - ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional * met->ny;
9946 if (gap > 0) {
9947 met->ny = met->ny + gap;
9948 WARN("Extended subdomains at the bottom to fit to full domain.");
9949 }
9950 }
9951
9952 /* Block-size, i.e. count */
9953 dd->subdomain_count[0] = 1;
9954 dd->subdomain_count[1] = (size_t) met->np;
9955 dd->subdomain_count[2] = (size_t) met->ny;
9956 dd->subdomain_count[3] = (size_t) met->nx;
9957
9958 /* Create halos and include them into the subdomain... */
9959 if (!left && !right) {
9960 // If we are not at the left or right edge extend in zonal direction...
9961 // Move the start one point to the left...
9962 dd->subdomain_count[3] =
9963 dd->subdomain_count[3] + (size_t) (ctl->dd_halos_size * 2);
9964 dd->subdomain_start[3] =
9965 dd->subdomain_start[3] - (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
9966 } else {
9967 // If we are at the left or right edge, extend only in one zonal direction...
9968 dd->subdomain_count[3] =
9969 dd->subdomain_count[3] + (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
9970 if (!left)
9971 // If we are not at the left edge, move the start to the left...
9972 dd->subdomain_start[3] =
9973 dd->subdomain_start[3] - (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
9974 }
9975
9976 if (!top && !bottom) {
9977 // If we are not at the upper or lower edge extend in meridional direction...
9978 // Move the start point one point down...
9979 dd->subdomain_count[2] =
9980 dd->subdomain_count[2] + (size_t) (ctl->dd_halos_size * 2);
9981 dd->subdomain_start[2] =
9982 dd->subdomain_start[2] - (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
9983 } else {
9984 // If we are at the top or the lower edge only extend in one mer. direction...
9985 dd->subdomain_count[2] =
9986 dd->subdomain_count[2] + (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
9987 if (!top)
9988 // If we are not at the top, move the start one upward...
9989 dd->subdomain_start[2] =
9990 dd->subdomain_start[2] - (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
9991 }
9992
9993 /* Set boundary halo hyperslabs ... */
9994 double lon_shift = 0;
9995 if (left || right) {
9996
9997 met->nx = met->nx + ctl->dd_halos_size;
9998
9999 dd->halo_bnd_start[0] = 0;
10000 dd->halo_bnd_start[1] = 0;
10001 dd->halo_bnd_start[3] = (size_t) (left ? (help_nx_glob - ctl->dd_halos_size) : (0)); //x
10002 dd->halo_bnd_start[2] = dd->subdomain_start[2]; //y
10003
10004 dd->halo_bnd_count[0] = 1;
10005 dd->halo_bnd_count[1] = (size_t) met->np;
10006 dd->halo_bnd_count[3] = (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size;
10007 dd->halo_bnd_count[2] =
10008 (size_t) met->ny +
10009 (size_t) ctl->dd_halos_size * ((top || bottom) ? 1 : 2);
10010
10011 dd->halo_offset_start = (left ? (int) dd->halo_bnd_count[3] : 0);
10012 dd->halo_offset_end = (left ? 0 : (int) dd->subdomain_count[3]);
10013 lon_shift = (left ? -360 : 360);
10014
10015 } else {
10016
10017 dd->halo_bnd_start[0] = 0;
10018 dd->halo_bnd_start[1] = 0;
10019 dd->halo_bnd_start[3] = 0;
10020 dd->halo_bnd_start[2] = 0;
10021
10022 dd->halo_bnd_count[0] = 0;
10023 dd->halo_bnd_count[1] = 0;
10024 dd->halo_bnd_count[3] = 0;
10025 dd->halo_bnd_count[2] = 0;
10026 }
10027
10028 /* Get the range of the entire meteodata... */
10029 /* Handle both periodic (global) and non-periodic (regional) longitude grids */
10030 double lon_range = 360;
10031 //if (dd_is_periodic_longitude(met, help_nx_glob)) {
10032 /* For global grids with periodic boundaries, use full 360 degrees */
10033 //lon_range = 360.0;
10034 //LOG(3, "Detected periodic longitude boundaries, using lon_range = 360.0");
10035 //} else {
10036 /* For regional grids, use the actual data range */
10037 //lon_range = help_lon_glob[help_nx_glob - 1] - help_lon_glob[0];
10038 //LOG(3, "Detected non-periodic longitude boundaries, using lon_range = %g", lon_range);
10039 //}
10040
10041 double lat_range = help_lat_glob[help_ny_glob - 1] - help_lat_glob[0];
10042
10043 /* Focus on subdomain latitudes and longitudes... */
10044 for (int iy = 0; iy < (int) dd->subdomain_count[2]; iy++)
10045 met->lat[iy] = help_lat_glob[(int) dd->subdomain_start[2] + iy];
10046
10047 /* Focus on subdomain longitudes... */
10048 /* Keep space at the beginning or end of the array for halo... */
10049 for (int ix = 0; ix < (int) dd->subdomain_count[3]; ix++)
10050 met->lon[ix + dd->halo_offset_start] =
10051 help_lon_glob[(int) dd->subdomain_start[3] + ix];
10052
10053 for (int ix = 0; ix < (int) dd->halo_bnd_count[3]; ix++)
10054 met->lon[ix + dd->halo_offset_end] =
10055 help_lon_glob[(int) dd->halo_bnd_start[3] + ix] + lon_shift;
10056
10057 /* Reset the grid dimensions... */
10058 met->nx = (int) dd->subdomain_count[3] + (int) dd->halo_bnd_count[3];
10059 met->ny = (int) dd->subdomain_count[2];
10060
10061 /* Determine subdomain edges... */
10062 dd->subdomain_lon_min = floor(dd->rank / ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional)
10063 * (lon_range) / (double) ctl->dd_subdomains_zonal;
10064 dd->subdomain_lon_max = dd->subdomain_lon_min
10065 + (lon_range) / (double) ctl->dd_subdomains_zonal;
10066
10067 /* Latitudes in descending order (90 to -90) */
10068 if (lat_range < 0) {
10069 dd->subdomain_lat_max = 90 + (dd->rank % ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional)
10070 * (lat_range) / (double) ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional;
10071 dd->subdomain_lat_min = dd->subdomain_lat_max
10072 + (lat_range) / (double) ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional;
10073 } else {
10074 WARN
10075 ("lat_range > 0, but is expected to be negative, i.e. latitudes should range from 90 to -90")
10076 dd->subdomain_lat_min = -90 + (dd->rank % ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional)
10077 * (lat_range) / (double) ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional;
10078 dd->subdomain_lat_max = dd->subdomain_lat_min
10079 + (lat_range) / (double) ctl->dd_subdomains_meridional;
10080 }
10081
10082 LOG(2, "Total longitude range: %g deg", lon_range);
10083 LOG(2, "Total latitude range: %g deg", lat_range);
10084
10085 LOG(2, "Define subdomain properties.");
10086 LOG(2, "MPI information: Rank %d, Size %d", dd->rank, dd->size);
10087 LOG(2, "Edge position: l=%d,r=%d,t=%d, b=%d", (int) left, (int) right,
10088 (int) top, (int) bottom);
10089 LOG(2, "Sizes for limits: EX %d EY %d EP %d", EX, EY, EP);
10090 LOG(2, "Total size for subdomain meteo data: nx %d ny %d np %d", met->nx,
10091 met->ny, met->np);
10092 LOG(2, "Hyperslab sizes for boundary halos: nx %d ny %d np %d",
10093 (int) dd->halo_bnd_count[3], (int) dd->halo_bnd_count[2],
10094 (int) dd->halo_bnd_count[1]);
10095 LOG(2, "Hyperslab sizes for subdomain and inner halos: nx %d ny %d np %d",
10096 (int) dd->subdomain_count[3], (int) dd->subdomain_count[2],
10097 (int) dd->subdomain_count[1]);
10098 LOG(2, "Subdomain start: nx %ld ny %ld np %ld", dd->subdomain_start[3],
10099 dd->subdomain_start[2], dd->subdomain_start[1]);
10100 LOG(2, "Boundary halo start: nx %ld ny %ld np %ld", dd->halo_bnd_start[3],
10101 dd->halo_bnd_start[2], dd->halo_bnd_start[1]);
10102 LOG(2, "Offsets: nx %d ny %d", dd->halo_offset_start, dd->halo_offset_end);
10103
10104 LOG(2, " %d Subdomain longitudes: %g, %g ... %g deg (edges: %g to %g)",
10105 dd->rank, met->lon[0], met->lon[1], met->lon[met->nx - 1],
10106 dd->subdomain_lon_min, dd->subdomain_lon_max);
10107 LOG(2, " %d Subdomain latitudes: %g, %g ... %g deg (edges: %g to %g)",
10108 dd->rank, met->lat[0], met->lat[1], met->lat[met->ny - 1],
10109 dd->subdomain_lat_min, dd->subdomain_lat_max);
10110
10111 free(help_lon_glob);
10112 free(help_lat_glob);
10113}

Domain decomposition size of halos given in grid-points.

◆ read_met_pbl()

void read_met_pbl ( const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met 
)

Computes the planetary boundary layer (PBL) pressure based on meteorological data.

This function determines the PBL pressure for each grid point using one of four methods: 0. Read PBL pressure from meteo data file.

  1. Read PBL heights from meteo data file and convert to pressure.
  2. Determine PBL pressure based on bulk Richardson number criterion.
  3. Determine PBL pressure Based on potential temperature difference. The calculated PBL height is constrained by user-defined minimum and maximum limits.
Parameters
[in]ctlPointer to the control structure (ctl_t), which contains parameters controlling the PBL calculation.
[in,out]metPointer to the meteorological data structure (met_t), which contains grid and atmospheric data. The met->pbl array is updated with the calculated PBL pressure.

Method 0 (Precomputed PBL pressure from file):

  • Read PBL pressure from meteo data file.

Method 1 (Precomputed PBL height from file):

  • Read PBL height from meteo data file.
  • Interpolates the PBL pressure using the geopotential heights from the meteo file.

Method 2 (Richardson number criterion):

  • Implements a method based on the bulk Richardson number (critical value: Ri = 0.25).
  • Iteratively evaluates vertical levels, calculating wind shear, and thermal gradients, until the Richardson number exceeds the critical threshold.
  • Interpolates between levels to find the precise height.

Method 3 (Potential temperature difference):

  • Computes the PBL height as the altitude where the potential temperature exceeds the surface value by 2 K.
  • Interpolates between levels to find the precise height.

Final Adjustments:

  • Ensures the PBL height respects user-defined minimum and maximum thresholds.
Note
Method 2 is a standard method for estimating PBL depths, but the current implementation seems to underestimate PBL depths compared to ECMWF PBL data or Method 3. Therefore, Method 3, is selected by default. If PBL heights are available from the meteo data files, it is recommended to select Method 1.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10117 of file mptrac.c.

10119 {
10120
10121 /* Set timer... */
10122 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_PBL", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10123 LOG(2, "Calculate planetary boundary layer...");
10124
10125 /* Convert PBL height from meteo file to pressure... */
10126 if (ctl->met_pbl == 1) {
10127
10128 /* Loop over grid points... */
10129#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10130 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10131 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10132
10133 /* Get pressure at top of PBL... */
10134 const float z = met->zs[ix][iy] + met->pbl[ix][iy];
10135 const int ip = locate_irr_float(met->z[ix][iy], met->np, z, 0);
10136 met->pbl[ix][iy] =
10137 (float) (LIN(met->z[ix][iy][ip], met->p[ip],
10138 met->z[ix][iy][ip + 1], met->p[ip + 1], z));
10139 }
10140 }
10141
10142 /* Determine PBL based on Richardson number... */
10143 else if (ctl->met_pbl == 2) {
10144
10145 /* Parameters used to estimate the height of the PBL
10146 (e.g., Vogelezang and Holtslag, 1996; Seidel et al., 2012)... */
10147 const double rib_crit = 0.25, dz = 0.05, umin = 5.0;
10148
10149 /* Loop over grid points... */
10150#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10151 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10152 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10153
10154 /* Set bottom level of PBL... */
10155 const double pbl_bot = met->ps[ix][iy] * exp(-dz / H0);
10156
10157 /* Find lowest level near the bottom... */
10158 int ip;
10159 for (ip = 1; ip < met->np; ip++)
10160 if (met->p[ip] < pbl_bot)
10161 break;
10162
10163 /* Get near surface data... */
10164 const double h2os = LIN(met->p[ip - 1], met->h2o[ix][iy][ip - 1],
10165 met->p[ip], met->h2o[ix][iy][ip], pbl_bot);
10166 const double tvs = THETAVIRT(pbl_bot, met->ts[ix][iy], h2os);
10167
10168 /* Init... */
10169 double rib_old = 0;
10170
10171 /* Loop over levels... */
10172 for (; ip < met->np; ip++) {
10173
10174 /* Get squared horizontal wind speed... */
10175 double vh2 = SQR(met->u[ix][iy][ip] - met->us[ix][iy])
10176 + SQR(met->v[ix][iy][ip] - met->vs[ix][iy]);
10177 vh2 = MAX(vh2, SQR(umin));
10178
10179 /* Calculate bulk Richardson number... */
10180 const double rib =
10181 G0 * 1e3 * (met->z[ix][iy][ip] - met->zs[ix][iy]) / tvs
10182 * (THETAVIRT(met->p[ip], met->t[ix][iy][ip],
10183 met->h2o[ix][iy][ip]) - tvs) / vh2;
10184
10185 /* Check for critical value... */
10186 if (rib >= rib_crit) {
10187 met->pbl[ix][iy] = (float) (LIN(rib_old, met->p[ip - 1],
10188 rib, met->p[ip], rib_crit));
10189 if (met->pbl[ix][iy] > pbl_bot)
10190 met->pbl[ix][iy] = (float) pbl_bot;
10191 break;
10192 }
10193
10194 /* Save Richardson number... */
10195 rib_old = rib;
10196 }
10197 }
10198 }
10199
10200 /* Determine PBL based on potential temperature... */
10201 if (ctl->met_pbl == 3) {
10202
10203 /* Parameters used to estimate the height of the PBL
10204 (following HYSPLIT model)... */
10205 const double dtheta = 2.0, zmin = 0.1;
10206
10207 /* Loop over grid points... */
10208#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10209 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10210 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10211
10212 /* Potential temperature at the surface... */
10213 const double theta0 = THETA(met->ps[ix][iy], met->ts[ix][iy]);
10214
10215 /* Find topmost level where theta exceeds surface value by 2 K... */
10216 int ip;
10217 for (ip = met->np - 2; ip > 0; ip--)
10218 if (met->p[ip] >= 300.)
10219 if (met->p[ip] > met->ps[ix][iy]
10220 || THETA(met->p[ip], met->t[ix][iy][ip]) <= theta0 + dtheta)
10221 break;
10222
10223 /* Interpolate... */
10224 met->pbl[ix][iy]
10225 = (float) (LIN(THETA(met->p[ip + 1], met->t[ix][iy][ip + 1]),
10226 met->p[ip + 1],
10227 THETA(met->p[ip], met->t[ix][iy][ip]),
10228 met->p[ip], theta0 + dtheta));
10229
10230 /* Check minimum value... */
10231 double pbl_min = met->ps[ix][iy] * exp(-zmin / H0);
10232 if (met->pbl[ix][iy] > pbl_min || met->p[ip] > met->ps[ix][iy])
10233 met->pbl[ix][iy] = (float) pbl_min;
10234 }
10235 }
10236
10237 /* Loop over grid points... */
10238#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10239 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10240 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10241
10242 /* Check minimum value... */
10243 double pbl_min = met->ps[ix][iy] * exp(-ctl->met_pbl_min / H0);
10244 met->pbl[ix][iy] = MIN(met->pbl[ix][iy], (float) pbl_min);
10245
10246 /* Check maximum value... */
10247 double pbl_max = met->ps[ix][iy] * exp(-ctl->met_pbl_max / H0);
10248 met->pbl[ix][iy] = MAX(met->pbl[ix][iy], (float) pbl_max);
10249 }
10250}
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ read_met_periodic()

void read_met_periodic ( met_t *  met)

Applies periodic boundary conditions to meteorological data along longitudinal axis.

This function applies periodic boundary conditions to meteorological data along the longitudinal axis. It checks if the difference between the last and first longitudes and the difference between the second and first longitudes are approximately equal to 360 degrees, indicating periodicity. If the condition is met, the function increases the longitude counter, sets the longitude value for the new grid point, and copies meteorological data from the first grid point to the last grid point to ensure periodicity.

Parameters
metA pointer to a structure containing meteorological data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets timer for performance monitoring.
  • Checks if the difference between the last and first longitudes and the difference between the second and first longitudes are approximately equal to 360 degrees, indicating periodicity.
  • If periodicity is confirmed:
    • Increases the longitude counter.
    • Sets the longitude value for the new grid point by adding the difference between the second and first longitudes to the longitude of the penultimate grid point.
    • Copies meteorological data from the first grid point to the last grid point to ensure periodicity:
      • Surface variables (e.g., pressure, temperature, wind speed, land-sea mask, sea surface temperature) are copied.
      • Meteorological variables at each pressure level are copied.
      • Meteorological variables at each hybrid pressure level are copied.
Note
This function is useful for generating continuous meteorological fields over a periodic domain, which is common in atmospheric modeling, especially for global simulations.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10254 of file mptrac.c.

10255 {
10256
10257 /* Set timer... */
10258 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_PERIODIC", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10259 LOG(2, "Apply periodic boundary conditions...");
10260
10261 /* Check longitudes... */
10262 if (!(fabs(met->lon[met->nx - 1] - met->lon[0]
10263 + met->lon[1] - met->lon[0] - 360) < 0.01))
10264 return;
10265
10266 /* Increase longitude counter... */
10267 if ((++met->nx) >= EX)
10268 ERRMSG("Cannot create periodic boundary conditions!");
10269
10270 /* Set longitude... */
10271 met->lon[met->nx - 1] = met->lon[met->nx - 2] + met->lon[1] - met->lon[0];
10272
10273 /* Loop over latitudes and pressure levels... */
10274#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10275 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10276 met->ps[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->ps[0][iy];
10277 met->zs[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->zs[0][iy];
10278 met->ts[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->ts[0][iy];
10279 met->us[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->us[0][iy];
10280 met->vs[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->vs[0][iy];
10281 met->ess[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->ess[0][iy];
10282 met->nss[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->nss[0][iy];
10283 met->shf[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->shf[0][iy];
10284 met->lsm[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->lsm[0][iy];
10285 met->sst[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->sst[0][iy];
10286 met->pbl[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->pbl[0][iy];
10287 met->cape[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->cape[0][iy];
10288 met->cin[met->nx - 1][iy] = met->cin[0][iy];
10289 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip++) {
10290 met->t[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->t[0][iy][ip];
10291 met->u[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->u[0][iy][ip];
10292 met->v[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->v[0][iy][ip];
10293 met->w[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->w[0][iy][ip];
10294 met->h2o[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->h2o[0][iy][ip];
10295 met->o3[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->o3[0][iy][ip];
10296 met->lwc[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->lwc[0][iy][ip];
10297 met->rwc[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->rwc[0][iy][ip];
10298 met->iwc[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->iwc[0][iy][ip];
10299 met->swc[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->swc[0][iy][ip];
10300 met->cc[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->cc[0][iy][ip];
10301 }
10302 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->npl; ip++) {
10303 met->ul[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->ul[0][iy][ip];
10304 met->vl[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->vl[0][iy][ip];
10305 met->wl[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->wl[0][iy][ip];
10306 met->pl[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->pl[0][iy][ip];
10307 met->zetal[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->zetal[0][iy][ip];
10308 met->zeta_dotl[met->nx - 1][iy][ip] = met->zeta_dotl[0][iy][ip];
10309 }
10310 }
10311}

◆ read_met_polar_winds()

void read_met_polar_winds ( met_t *  met)

Applies a fix for polar winds in meteorological data.

This function applies a fix for polar winds in meteorological data, particularly focusing on the u and v wind components. It checks if the latitudes at the top and bottom of the grid are close to the poles. If so, it transforms the winds at 89-degree latitude into Cartesian coordinates, takes their mean, and replaces the winds at 90-degree latitude with this mean, effectively fixing the unrealistic behavior of winds at the poles.

Parameters
metA pointer to a structure containing meteorological data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets a timer for performance monitoring.
  • Checks if the latitudes at the top and bottom of the grid are close to the poles (within 0.001 degree latitude of the poles).
  • For each hemisphere (north and south):
    • Sets latitude indices for 89 degrees and 90 degrees.
    • Determines the sign of longitude adjustments based on the hemisphere.
    • Constructs lookup tables for cosine and sine of longitudes.
    • Loops over pressure levels and performs the following operations:
      • Transforms u and v wind components at 89 degrees latitude into Cartesian coordinates and calculates their mean.
      • Replaces u and v wind components at 90 degrees latitude with the calculated mean, effectively fixing the polar winds.
Note
This function is useful for correcting unrealistic behavior of winds near the poles in meteorological data, which can affect various atmospheric simulations.
Based on a Python code provided by Jens-Uwe Grooß.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10315 of file mptrac.c.

10316 {
10317
10318 /* Set timer... */
10319 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_POLAR_WINDS", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10320 LOG(2, "Apply fix for polar winds...");
10321
10322 /* Check latitudes... */
10323 if (fabs(met->lat[0]) < 89.999 || fabs(met->lat[met->ny - 1]) < 89.999)
10324 return;
10325
10326 /* Loop over hemispheres... */
10327 for (int ihem = 0; ihem < 2; ihem++) {
10328
10329 /* Set latitude indices... */
10330 int i89 = 1, i90 = 0, sign = 1;
10331 if (ihem == 1) {
10332 i89 = met->ny - 2;
10333 i90 = met->ny - 1;
10334 }
10335 if (met->lat[i90] < 0)
10336 sign = -1;
10337
10338 /* Look-up table of cosinus and sinus... */
10339 double clon[EX], slon[EX];
10340#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10341 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++) {
10342 clon[ix] = cos(sign * DEG2RAD(met->lon[ix]));
10343 slon[ix] = sin(sign * DEG2RAD(met->lon[ix]));
10344 }
10345
10346 /* Loop over levels... */
10347#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10348 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip++) {
10349
10350 /* Transform 89 degree u and v winds into Cartesian coordinates and take the mean... */
10351 double vel89x = 0, vel89y = 0;
10352 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++) {
10353 vel89x +=
10354 (met->u[ix][i89][ip] * clon[ix] -
10355 met->v[ix][i89][ip] * slon[ix]) / met->nx;
10356 vel89y +=
10357 (met->u[ix][i89][ip] * slon[ix] +
10358 met->v[ix][i89][ip] * clon[ix]) / met->nx;
10359 }
10360
10361 /* Replace 90 degree winds by 89 degree mean... */
10362 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++) {
10363 met->u[ix][i90][ip]
10364 = (float) (vel89x * clon[ix] + vel89y * slon[ix]);
10365 met->v[ix][i90][ip]
10366 = (float) (-vel89x * slon[ix] + vel89y * clon[ix]);
10367 }
10368 }
10369 }
10370}

◆ read_met_pv()

void read_met_pv ( met_t *  met)

Calculates potential vorticity (PV) from meteorological data.

This function calculates the potential vorticity (PV) from the provided meteorological data. It employs finite difference methods to estimate gradients of temperature, wind components, and pressure in longitude, latitude, and pressure dimensions. These gradients are then used to compute PV at each grid point. Additionally, a fix for polar regions is applied to ensure smoothness of PV values in these regions.

Parameters
metA pointer to a structure containing meteorological data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets a timer for performance monitoring.
  • Computes powers for pressure calculation.
  • Loops over grid points in longitude:
    • Sets latitude indices.
    • Loops over grid points in latitude:
      • Sets indices and auxiliary variables.
      • Loops over pressure levels:
        • Computes gradients in longitude, latitude, and pressure.
        • Calculates PV using computed gradients.
  • Applies a fix for polar regions to ensure smoothness of PV values.
Note
Potential vorticity is a fundamental quantity in atmospheric dynamics, representing the potential of a fluid parcel to rotate due to changes in pressure, temperature, and wind fields.
Based on a Python code by Mathew Barlow (https://github.com/mathewbarlow/potential-vorticity).
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10374 of file mptrac.c.

10375 {
10376
10377 double pows[EP];
10378
10379 /* Set timer... */
10380 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_PV", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10381 LOG(2, "Calculate potential vorticity...");
10382
10383 /* Set powers... */
10384#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10385 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip++)
10386 pows[ip] = pow(1000. / met->p[ip], 0.286);
10387
10388 /* Loop over grid points... */
10389#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10390 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++) {
10391
10392 /* Set indices... */
10393 const int ix0 = MAX(ix - 1, 0);
10394 const int ix1 = MIN(ix + 1, met->nx - 1);
10395
10396 /* Loop over grid points... */
10397 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10398
10399 /* Set indices... */
10400 const int iy0 = MAX(iy - 1, 0);
10401 const int iy1 = MIN(iy + 1, met->ny - 1);
10402
10403 /* Set auxiliary variables... */
10404 const double latr = 0.5 * (met->lat[iy1] + met->lat[iy0]);
10405 const double dx = 1000. * DEG2DX(met->lon[ix1] - met->lon[ix0], latr);
10406 const double dy = 1000. * DEG2DY(met->lat[iy1] - met->lat[iy0]);
10407 const double c0 = cos(DEG2RAD(met->lat[iy0]));
10408 const double c1 = cos(DEG2RAD(met->lat[iy1]));
10409 const double cr = cos(DEG2RAD(latr));
10410 const double vort = 2 * 7.2921e-5 * sin(DEG2RAD(latr));
10411
10412 /* Loop over grid points... */
10413 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip++) {
10414
10415 /* Get gradients in longitude... */
10416 const double dtdx
10417 = (met->t[ix1][iy][ip] - met->t[ix0][iy][ip]) * pows[ip] / dx;
10418 const double dvdx = (met->v[ix1][iy][ip] - met->v[ix0][iy][ip]) / dx;
10419
10420 /* Get gradients in latitude... */
10421 const double dtdy
10422 = (met->t[ix][iy1][ip] - met->t[ix][iy0][ip]) * pows[ip] / dy;
10423 const double dudy
10424 = (met->u[ix][iy1][ip] * c1 - met->u[ix][iy0][ip] * c0) / dy;
10425
10426 /* Set indices... */
10427 const int ip0 = MAX(ip - 1, 0);
10428 const int ip1 = MIN(ip + 1, met->np - 1);
10429
10430 /* Get gradients in pressure... */
10431 double dtdp, dudp, dvdp;
10432 const double dp0 = 100. * (met->p[ip] - met->p[ip0]);
10433 const double dp1 = 100. * (met->p[ip1] - met->p[ip]);
10434 if (ip != ip0 && ip != ip1) {
10435 double denom = dp0 * dp1 * (dp0 + dp1);
10436 dtdp = (dp0 * dp0 * met->t[ix][iy][ip1] * pows[ip1]
10437 - dp1 * dp1 * met->t[ix][iy][ip0] * pows[ip0]
10438 + (dp1 * dp1 - dp0 * dp0) * met->t[ix][iy][ip] * pows[ip])
10439 / denom;
10440 dudp = (dp0 * dp0 * met->u[ix][iy][ip1]
10441 - dp1 * dp1 * met->u[ix][iy][ip0]
10442 + (dp1 * dp1 - dp0 * dp0) * met->u[ix][iy][ip])
10443 / denom;
10444 dvdp = (dp0 * dp0 * met->v[ix][iy][ip1]
10445 - dp1 * dp1 * met->v[ix][iy][ip0]
10446 + (dp1 * dp1 - dp0 * dp0) * met->v[ix][iy][ip])
10447 / denom;
10448 } else {
10449 const double denom = dp0 + dp1;
10450 dtdp =
10451 (met->t[ix][iy][ip1] * pows[ip1] -
10452 met->t[ix][iy][ip0] * pows[ip0]) / denom;
10453 dudp = (met->u[ix][iy][ip1] - met->u[ix][iy][ip0]) / denom;
10454 dvdp = (met->v[ix][iy][ip1] - met->v[ix][iy][ip0]) / denom;
10455 }
10456
10457 /* Calculate PV... */
10458 met->pv[ix][iy][ip] = (float)
10459 (1e6 * G0 *
10460 (-dtdp * (dvdx - dudy / cr + vort) + dvdp * dtdx - dudp * dtdy));
10461 }
10462 }
10463 }
10464
10465 /* Fix for polar regions... */
10466#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10467 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10468 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip++) {
10469 met->pv[ix][0][ip]
10470 = met->pv[ix][1][ip]
10471 = met->pv[ix][2][ip];
10472 met->pv[ix][met->ny - 1][ip]
10473 = met->pv[ix][met->ny - 2][ip]
10474 = met->pv[ix][met->ny - 3][ip];
10475 }
10476}
DEG2DY
#define DEG2DY(dlat)
Convert a latitude difference to a distance in the y-direction (north-south).
Definition: mptrac.h:528
DEG2DX
#define DEG2DX(dlon, lat)
Convert a longitude difference to a distance in the x-direction (east-west) at a specific latitude.
Definition: mptrac.h:507

◆ read_met_ozone()

void read_met_ozone ( met_t *  met)

Calculates the total column ozone from meteorological ozone data.

This function calculates the total column ozone from the provided meteorological ozone data. It integrates ozone concentrations over altitude to obtain the column ozone density. The result is then converted to Dobson units, which represent the thickness of the ozone layer if compressed into one layer at standard temperature and pressure.

Parameters
metA pointer to a structure containing meteorological ozone data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets a timer for performance monitoring.
  • Loops over columns in longitude and latitude:
    • Integrates ozone concentrations over altitude.
    • Converts the integrated ozone density to Dobson units.
Note
Total column ozone is a critical metric for understanding ozone distribution in the atmosphere, with implications for climate, air quality, and UV radiation.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10480 of file mptrac.c.

10481 {
10482
10483 /* Set timer... */
10484 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_OZONE", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10485 LOG(2, "Calculate total column ozone...");
10486
10487 /* Loop over columns... */
10488#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10489 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10490 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10491
10492 /* Integrate... */
10493 double cd = 0;
10494 for (int ip = 1; ip < met->np; ip++)
10495 if (met->p[ip - 1] <= met->ps[ix][iy]) {
10496 const double vmr =
10497 0.5 * (met->o3[ix][iy][ip - 1] + met->o3[ix][iy][ip]);
10498 const double dp = met->p[ip - 1] - met->p[ip];
10499 cd += vmr * MO3 / MA * dp * 1e2 / G0;
10500 }
10501
10502 /* Convert to Dobson units... */
10503 met->o3c[ix][iy] = (float) (cd / 2.1415e-5);
10504 }
10505}

◆ read_met_sample()

void read_met_sample ( const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met 
)

Downsamples meteorological data based on specified parameters.

This function downsamples meteorological data based on the provided control parameters. It reduces the resolution of meteorological data by averaging over specified intervals in longitude, latitude, and altitude.

Parameters
ctlA pointer to a structure containing control parameters for downsampling.
metA pointer to a structure containing meteorological data to be downsampled.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Checks if downsampling parameters are set to a value less than or equal to 1, if so, returns without downsampling.
  • Sets a timer for performance monitoring.
  • Allocates memory for a temporary meteorological data structure.
  • Copies metadata from the original structure to the temporary structure.
  • Performs downsampling by smoothing over specified intervals:
    • Computes weighted averages over the specified intervals.
    • Updates the temporary structure with the smoothed values.
  • Downsamples the smoothed data:
    • Updates longitude and latitude arrays with downsampled values.
    • Stores downsampled meteorological variables in the original structure.
  • Frees memory allocated for the temporary structure.
Note
Downsampling meteorological data can be useful for reducing computational cost while preserving essential features for modeling and analysis.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10509 of file mptrac.c.

10511 {
10512
10513 met_t *help;
10514
10515 /* Check parameters... */
10516 if (ctl->met_dp <= 1 && ctl->met_dx <= 1 && ctl->met_dy <= 1
10517 && ctl->met_sp <= 1 && ctl->met_sx <= 1 && ctl->met_sy <= 1)
10518 return;
10519
10520 /* Set timer... */
10521 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_SAMPLE", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10522 LOG(2, "Downsampling of meteo data...");
10523
10524 /* Allocate... */
10525 ALLOC(help, met_t, 1);
10526
10527 /* Copy data... */
10528 help->nx = met->nx;
10529 help->ny = met->ny;
10530 help->np = met->np;
10531 memcpy(help->lon, met->lon, sizeof(met->lon));
10532 memcpy(help->lat, met->lat, sizeof(met->lat));
10533 memcpy(help->p, met->p, sizeof(met->p));
10534
10535 /* Smoothing... */
10536 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix += ctl->met_dx) {
10537 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy += ctl->met_dy) {
10538 for (int ip = 0; ip < met->np; ip += ctl->met_dp) {
10539 help->ps[ix][iy] = 0;
10540 help->zs[ix][iy] = 0;
10541 help->ts[ix][iy] = 0;
10542 help->us[ix][iy] = 0;
10543 help->vs[ix][iy] = 0;
10544 help->ess[ix][iy] = 0;
10545 help->nss[ix][iy] = 0;
10546 help->shf[ix][iy] = 0;
10547 help->lsm[ix][iy] = 0;
10548 help->sst[ix][iy] = 0;
10549 help->pbl[ix][iy] = 0;
10550 help->cape[ix][iy] = 0;
10551 help->cin[ix][iy] = 0;
10552 help->t[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10553 help->u[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10554 help->v[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10555 help->w[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10556 help->h2o[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10557 help->o3[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10558 help->lwc[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10559 help->rwc[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10560 help->iwc[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10561 help->swc[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10562 help->cc[ix][iy][ip] = 0;
10563 float wsum = 0;
10564 for (int ix2 = ix - ctl->met_sx + 1; ix2 <= ix + ctl->met_sx - 1;
10565 ix2++) {
10566 int ix3 = ix2;
10567 if (ix3 < 0)
10568 ix3 += met->nx;
10569 else if (ix3 >= met->nx)
10570 ix3 -= met->nx;
10571
10572 for (int iy2 = MAX(iy - ctl->met_sy + 1, 0);
10573 iy2 <= MIN(iy + ctl->met_sy - 1, met->ny - 1); iy2++)
10574 for (int ip2 = MAX(ip - ctl->met_sp + 1, 0);
10575 ip2 <= MIN(ip + ctl->met_sp - 1, met->np - 1); ip2++) {
10576 const float w =
10577 (1.0f - (float) abs(ix - ix2) / (float) ctl->met_sx)
10578 * (1.0f - (float) abs(iy - iy2) / (float) ctl->met_sy)
10579 * (1.0f - (float) abs(ip - ip2) / (float) ctl->met_sp);
10580 help->ps[ix][iy] += w * met->ps[ix3][iy2];
10581 help->zs[ix][iy] += w * met->zs[ix3][iy2];
10582 help->ts[ix][iy] += w * met->ts[ix3][iy2];
10583 help->us[ix][iy] += w * met->us[ix3][iy2];
10584 help->vs[ix][iy] += w * met->vs[ix3][iy2];
10585 help->ess[ix][iy] += w * met->ess[ix3][iy2];
10586 help->nss[ix][iy] += w * met->nss[ix3][iy2];
10587 help->shf[ix][iy] += w * met->shf[ix3][iy2];
10588 help->lsm[ix][iy] += w * met->lsm[ix3][iy2];
10589 help->sst[ix][iy] += w * met->sst[ix3][iy2];
10590 help->pbl[ix][iy] += w * met->pbl[ix3][iy2];
10591 help->cape[ix][iy] += w * met->cape[ix3][iy2];
10592 help->cin[ix][iy] += w * met->cin[ix3][iy2];
10593 help->t[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->t[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10594 help->u[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->u[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10595 help->v[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->v[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10596 help->w[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->w[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10597 help->h2o[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->h2o[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10598 help->o3[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->o3[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10599 help->lwc[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->lwc[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10600 help->rwc[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->rwc[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10601 help->iwc[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->iwc[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10602 help->swc[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->swc[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10603 help->cc[ix][iy][ip] += w * met->cc[ix3][iy2][ip2];
10604 wsum += w;
10605 }
10606 }
10607 help->ps[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10608 help->zs[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10609 help->ts[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10610 help->us[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10611 help->vs[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10612 help->ess[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10613 help->nss[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10614 help->shf[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10615 help->lsm[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10616 help->sst[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10617 help->pbl[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10618 help->cape[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10619 help->cin[ix][iy] /= wsum;
10620 help->t[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10621 help->u[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10622 help->v[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10623 help->w[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10624 help->h2o[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10625 help->o3[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10626 help->lwc[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10627 help->rwc[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10628 help->iwc[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10629 help->swc[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10630 help->cc[ix][iy][ip] /= wsum;
10631 }
10632 }
10633 }
10634
10635 /* Downsampling... */
10636 met->nx = 0;
10637 for (int ix = 0; ix < help->nx; ix += ctl->met_dx) {
10638 met->lon[met->nx] = help->lon[ix];
10639 met->ny = 0;
10640 for (int iy = 0; iy < help->ny; iy += ctl->met_dy) {
10641 met->lat[met->ny] = help->lat[iy];
10642 met->ps[met->nx][met->ny] = help->ps[ix][iy];
10643 met->zs[met->nx][met->ny] = help->zs[ix][iy];
10644 met->ts[met->nx][met->ny] = help->ts[ix][iy];
10645 met->us[met->nx][met->ny] = help->us[ix][iy];

10657 met->p[met->np] = help->p[ip];
10658 met->t[met->nx][met->ny][met->np] = help->t[ix][iy][ip];
10659 met->u[met->nx][met->ny][met->np] = help->u[ix][iy][ip];

10667 met->swc[met->nx][met->ny][met->np] = help->swc[ix][iy][ip];
10668 met->cc[met->nx][met->ny][met->np] = help->cc[ix][iy][ip];
10669 met->np++;
10670 }
10671 met->ny++;
10672 }
10673 met->nx++;
10674 }

10678}

◆ read_met_tropo()

void read_met_tropo ( const ctl_t *  ctl,
const clim_t *  clim,
met_t *  met 
)

Calculates the tropopause and related meteorological variables based on various methods and stores the results in the meteorological data structure.

This function calculates the tropopause and related meteorological variables using different methods specified by the control parameters. The calculated tropopause pressure is stored in the provided meteorological data structure.

Parameters
ctlA pointer to a structure containing control parameters.
climA pointer to the climatological data structure.
metA pointer to the meteorological data structure to store the calculated tropopause pressure and related variables.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets a timer for performance monitoring.
  • Retrieves altitude and pressure profiles from the meteorological data structure.
  • Depending on the control parameters (ctl->met_tropo), it calculates the tropopause using one of the following methods:
    • If ctl->met_tropo == 0, it does not calculate the tropopause and assigns NaN values to the tropopause pressure.
    • If ctl->met_tropo == 1, it uses tropopause climatology to estimate the tropopause pressure based on latitude and time.
    • If ctl->met_tropo == 2, it calculates the tropopause based on the cold point method, finding the altitude where the temperature is at a minimum.
    • If ctl->met_tropo == 3 or ctl->met_tropo == 4, it calculates the tropopause using the WMO definition, which involves identifying a sharp temperature lapse rate between two pressure levels.
    • If ctl->met_tropo == 5, it calculates the dynamical tropopause based on potential vorticity and potential temperature profiles.
  • Interpolates temperature, geopotential height, and water vapor content to the tropopause pressure level using spatial interpolation.
  • Stores the interpolated values in the meteorological data structure.
Note
The function supports parallelization using OpenMP directives to improve performance.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10682 of file mptrac.c.

10685 {
10686
10687 double p2[200], pv[EP], pv2[200], t[EP], t2[200], th[EP],
10688 th2[200], z[EP], z2[200];
10689
10690 /* Set timer... */
10691 SELECT_TIMER("READ_MET_TROPO", "METPROC", NVTX_READ);
10692 LOG(2, "Calculate tropopause...");
10693
10694 /* Get altitude and pressure profiles... */
10695#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10696 for (int iz = 0; iz < met->np; iz++)
10697 z[iz] = Z(met->p[iz]);
10698#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
10699 for (int iz = 0; iz <= 190; iz++) {
10700 z2[iz] = 4.5 + 0.1 * iz;
10701 p2[iz] = P(z2[iz]);
10702 }
10703
10704 /* Do not calculate tropopause... */
10705 if (ctl->met_tropo == 0)
10706#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10707 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10708 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++)
10709 met->pt[ix][iy] = NAN;
10710
10711 /* Use tropopause climatology... */
10712 else if (ctl->met_tropo == 1) {
10713#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10714 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10715 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++)
10716 met->pt[ix][iy] = (float) clim_tropo(clim, met->time, met->lat[iy]);
10717 }
10718
10719 /* Use cold point... */
10720 else if (ctl->met_tropo == 2) {
10721
10722 /* Loop over grid points... */
10723#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) private(t,t2) collapse(2)
10724 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10725 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10726
10727 /* Interpolate temperature profile... */
10728 for (int iz = 0; iz < met->np; iz++)
10729 t[iz] = met->t[ix][iy][iz];
10730 spline(z, t, met->np, z2, t2, 171, ctl->met_tropo_spline);
10731
10732 /* Find minimum... */
10733 int iz = (int) gsl_stats_min_index(t2, 1, 171);
10734 if (iz > 0 && iz < 170)
10735 met->pt[ix][iy] = (float) p2[iz];
10736 else
10737 met->pt[ix][iy] = NAN;
10738 }
10739 }
10740
10741 /* Use WMO definition... */
10742 else if (ctl->met_tropo == 3 || ctl->met_tropo == 4) {
10743
10744 /* Loop over grid points... */
10745#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) private(t,t2) collapse(2)
10746 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10747 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10748
10749 /* Interpolate temperature profile... */
10750 int iz;
10751 for (iz = 0; iz < met->np; iz++)
10752 t[iz] = met->t[ix][iy][iz];
10753 spline(z, t, met->np, z2, t2, 191, ctl->met_tropo_spline);
10754
10755 /* Find 1st tropopause... */
10756 met->pt[ix][iy] = NAN;
10757 for (iz = 0; iz <= 170; iz++) {
10758 int found = 1;
10759 for (int iz2 = iz + 1; iz2 <= iz + 20; iz2++)
10760 if (LAPSE(p2[iz], t2[iz], p2[iz2], t2[iz2]) > 2.0) {
10761 found = 0;
10762 break;
10763 }
10764 if (found) {
10765 if (iz > 0 && iz < 170)
10766 met->pt[ix][iy] = (float) p2[iz];
10767 break;
10768 }
10769 }
10770
10771 /* Find 2nd tropopause... */
10772 if (ctl->met_tropo == 4) {
10773 met->pt[ix][iy] = NAN;
10774 for (; iz <= 170; iz++) {
10775 int found = 1;
10776 for (int iz2 = iz + 1; iz2 <= iz + 10; iz2++)
10777 if (LAPSE(p2[iz], t2[iz], p2[iz2], t2[iz2]) < 3.0) {
10778 found = 0;
10779 break;
10780 }
10781 if (found)
10782 break;
10783 }
10784 for (; iz <= 170; iz++) {
10785 int found = 1;
10786 for (int iz2 = iz + 1; iz2 <= iz + 20; iz2++)
10787 if (LAPSE(p2[iz], t2[iz], p2[iz2], t2[iz2]) > 2.0) {
10788 found = 0;
10789 break;
10790 }
10791 if (found) {
10792 if (iz > 0 && iz < 170)
10793 met->pt[ix][iy] = (float) p2[iz];
10794 break;
10795 }
10796 }
10797 }
10798 }
10799 }
10800
10801 /* Use dynamical tropopause... */
10802 else if (ctl->met_tropo == 5) {
10803
10804 /* Loop over grid points... */
10805#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) private(pv,pv2,th,th2) collapse(2)
10806 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10807 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10808
10809 /* Interpolate potential vorticity profile... */
10810 for (int iz = 0; iz < met->np; iz++)
10811 pv[iz] = met->pv[ix][iy][iz];
10812 spline(z, pv, met->np, z2, pv2, 171, ctl->met_tropo_spline);
10813
10814 /* Interpolate potential temperature profile... */
10815 for (int iz = 0; iz < met->np; iz++)
10816 th[iz] = THETA(met->p[iz], met->t[ix][iy][iz]);
10817 spline(z, th, met->np, z2, th2, 171, ctl->met_tropo_spline);
10818
10819 /* Find dynamical tropopause... */
10820 met->pt[ix][iy] = NAN;
10821 for (int iz = 0; iz <= 170; iz++)
10822 if (fabs(pv2[iz]) >= ctl->met_tropo_pv
10823 || th2[iz] >= ctl->met_tropo_theta) {
10824 if (iz > 0 && iz < 170)
10825 met->pt[ix][iy] = (float) p2[iz];
10826 break;
10827 }
10828 }
10829 }
10830
10831 else
10832 ERRMSG("Cannot calculate tropopause!");
10833
10834 /* Interpolate temperature, geopotential height, and water vapor... */
10835#pragma omp parallel for default(shared) collapse(2)
10836 for (int ix = 0; ix < met->nx; ix++)
10837 for (int iy = 0; iy < met->ny; iy++) {
10838 double h2ot, tt, zt;
10839 INTPOL_INIT;
10840 intpol_met_space_3d(met, met->t, met->pt[ix][iy], met->lon[ix],
10841 met->lat[iy], &tt, ci, cw, 1);
10842 intpol_met_space_3d(met, met->z, met->pt[ix][iy], met->lon[ix],
10843 met->lat[iy], &zt, ci, cw, 0);
10844 intpol_met_space_3d(met, met->h2o, met->pt[ix][iy], met->lon[ix],
10845 met->lat[iy], &h2ot, ci, cw, 0);
10846 met->tt[ix][iy] = (float) tt;
10847 met->zt[ix][iy] = (float) zt;
10848 met->h2ot[ix][iy] = (float) h2ot;
10849 }
10850}
spline
void spline(const double *x, const double *y, const int n, const double *x2, double *y2, const int n2, const int method)
Performs spline interpolation or linear interpolation.
Definition: mptrac.c:11060
LAPSE
#define LAPSE(p1, t1, p2, t2)
Calculate lapse rate.
Definition: mptrac.h:969

◆ read_obs()

void read_obs ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
double *  rt,
double *  rz,
double *  rlon,
double *  rlat,
double *  robs,
int *  nobs 
)

Reads observation data from a file and stores it in arrays.

This function reads observation data from a specified file in either ASCII or NetCDF format, depending on the value of the OBS_TYPE control parameter. It stores the time, altitude, longitude, latitude, and observation values in the provided arrays.

Parameters
filenameThe path to the observation data file.
ctlA pointer to a structure containing control parameters.
rtAn array to store the time values of the observations.
rzAn array to store the altitude values of the observations.
rlonAn array to store the longitude values of the observations.
rlatAn array to store the latitude values of the observations.
robsAn array to store the observation values.
nobsA pointer to an integer variable to store the number of observations read.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Logs an informational message indicating the observation data file being read.
  • Reads the observation data from the file based on the OBS_TYPE control parameter:
    • If ctl->obs_type == 0, it reads the data from an ASCII file using the read_obs_asc function.
    • If ctl->obs_type == 1, it reads the data from a NetCDF file using the read_obs_nc function.
    • If ctl->obs_type is neither 0 nor 1, it generates an error message indicating that the OBS_TYPE must be set to 0 or 1.
  • Checks if the time values are in ascending order and generates an error message if not.
  • Logs statistical information about the observation data, including the number of observations, time range, altitude range, longitude range, latitude range, and observation value range.
Note
The function assumes that the observation data file is formatted correctly and that the arrays provided have sufficient memory allocated to store the data.
Author
Lars Hoffmann
Mingzhao Liu

Definition at line 10854 of file mptrac.c.

10862 {
10863
10864 /* Write info... */
10865 LOG(1, "Read observation data: %s", filename);
10866
10867 /* Read data... */
10868 if (ctl->obs_type == 0)
10869 read_obs_asc(filename, rt, rz, rlon, rlat, robs, nobs);
10870 else if (ctl->obs_type == 1)
10871 read_obs_nc(filename, rt, rz, rlon, rlat, robs, nobs);
10872 else
10873 ERRMSG("Set OBS_TYPE to 0 or 1!");
10874
10875 /* Check time... */
10876 for (int i = 1; i < *nobs; i++)
10877 if (rt[i] < rt[i - 1])
10878 ERRMSG("Time must be ascending!");
10879
10880 /* Write info... */
10881 int n = *nobs;
10882 double mini, maxi;
10883 LOG(2, "Number of observations: %d", *nobs);
10884 gsl_stats_minmax(&mini, &maxi, rt, 1, (size_t) n);
10885 LOG(2, "Time range: %.2f ... %.2f s", mini, maxi);
10886 gsl_stats_minmax(&mini, &maxi, rz, 1, (size_t) n);
10887 LOG(2, "Altitude range: %g ... %g km", mini, maxi);
10888 gsl_stats_minmax(&mini, &maxi, rlon, 1, (size_t) n);
10889 LOG(2, "Longitude range: %g ... %g deg", mini, maxi);
10890 gsl_stats_minmax(&mini, &maxi, rlat, 1, (size_t) n);
10891 LOG(2, "Latitude range: %g ... %g deg", mini, maxi);
10892 gsl_stats_minmax(&mini, &maxi, robs, 1, (size_t) n);
10893 LOG(2, "Observation range: %g ... %g", mini, maxi);
10894}
read_obs_asc
void read_obs_asc(const char *filename, double *rt, double *rz, double *rlon, double *rlat, double *robs, int *nobs)
