◆ read_obs_asc()

void read_obs_asc ( const char *  filename,
double *  rt,
double *  rz,
double *  rlon,
double *  rlat,
double *  robs,
int *  nobs 
)

Reads observation data from an ASCII file.

This function reads observation data from a specified ASCII file. It extracts time, altitude, longitude, latitude, and observation values from each line of the file and stores them in the provided arrays.

Parameters
filenameThe path to the ASCII file containing the observation data.
rtAn array to store the time values of the observations.
rzAn array to store the altitude values of the observations.
rlonAn array to store the longitude values of the observations.
rlatAn array to store the latitude values of the observations.
robsAn array to store the observation values.
nobsA pointer to an integer variable to store the number of observations read.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Attempts to open the specified observation data file in read mode.
  • Reads each line of the file and parses it to extract the time, altitude, longitude, latitude, and observation values using the sscanf function.
  • Stores the extracted values in the respective arrays.
  • Checks if the number of observations exceeds the maximum allowed limit (NOBS) and generates an error message if so.
  • Closes the observation data file after reading all data.
Note
The function assumes that the observation data file is properly formatted and that the arrays provided have sufficient memory allocated to store the data.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10898 of file mptrac.c.

10905 {
10906
10907 /* Open observation data file... */
10908 FILE *in;
10909 if (!(in = fopen(filename, "r")))
10910 ERRMSG("Cannot open file!");
10911
10912 /* Read observations... */
10913 char line[LEN];
10914 while (fgets(line, LEN, in))
10915 if (sscanf(line, "%lg %lg %lg %lg %lg", &rt[*nobs], &rz[*nobs],
10916 &rlon[*nobs], &rlat[*nobs], &robs[*nobs]) == 5)
10917 if ((++(*nobs)) >= NOBS)
10918 ERRMSG("Too many observations!");
10919
10920 /* Close observation data file... */
10921 fclose(in);
10922}
NOBS
#define NOBS
Maximum number of observation data points.
Definition: mptrac.h:328

◆ read_obs_nc()

void read_obs_nc ( const char *  filename,
double *  rt,
double *  rz,
double *  rlon,
double *  rlat,
double *  robs,
int *  nobs 
)

Reads observation data from a NetCDF file.

This function reads observation data from a specified NetCDF file. It extracts time, altitude, longitude, latitude, and observation values from the variables in the NetCDF file and stores them in the provided arrays.

Parameters
filenameThe path to the NetCDF file containing the observation data.
rtAn array to store the time values of the observations.
rzAn array to store the altitude values of the observations.
rlonAn array to store the longitude values of the observations.
rlatAn array to store the latitude values of the observations.
robsAn array to store the observation values.
nobsA pointer to an integer variable to store the number of observations read.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Attempts to open the specified NetCDF file in read-only mode using the nc_open function.
  • Queries the dimensions of the 'nobs' variable in the NetCDF file to determine the number of observations using the NC_INQ_DIM macro.
  • Reads the 'time', 'alt', 'lon', 'lat', and 'obs' variables from the NetCDF file using the NC_GET_DOUBLE macro and stores them in the respective arrays.
  • Closes the NetCDF file after reading all data using the nc_close function.
Note
The function assumes that the NetCDF file contains the required variables ('time', 'alt', 'lon', 'lat', 'obs') and that the arrays provided have sufficient memory allocated to store the data.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10926 of file mptrac.c.

10933 {
10934
10935 int ncid, varid;
10936
10937 /* Open netCDF file... */
10938 if (nc_open(filename, NC_NOWRITE, &ncid) != NC_NOERR)
10939 ERRMSG("Cannot open file!");
10940
10941 /* Read the observations from the NetCDF file... */
10942 NC_INQ_DIM("nobs", nobs, 1, NOBS, 1);
10943 NC_GET_DOUBLE("time", rt, 1);
10944 NC_GET_DOUBLE("alt", rz, 1);
10945 NC_GET_DOUBLE("lon", rlon, 1);
10946 NC_GET_DOUBLE("lat", rlat, 1);
10947 NC_GET_DOUBLE("obs", robs, 1);
10948
10949 /* Close file... */
10950 NC(nc_close(ncid));
10951}

◆ scan_ctl()

double scan_ctl ( const char *  filename,
int  argc,
char *  argv[],
const char *  varname,
const int  arridx,
const char *  defvalue,
char *  value 
)

Scans a control file or command-line arguments for a specified variable.

This function scans either a control file or command-line arguments for a specified variable name and retrieves its value. It searches for the variable name in the control file or command-line arguments and returns its corresponding value. If the variable is not found, it returns a default value specified by the user.

Parameters
filenameThe name of the control file to be scanned. If NULL, only command-line arguments will be scanned.
argcThe number of command-line arguments.
argvAn array of command-line arguments.
varnameThe name of the variable to be searched.
arridxThe index of the variable array, if applicable. Set to -1 if not an array.
defvalueThe default value to be returned if the variable is not found.
valueA pointer to a character array to store the retrieved value.
Returns
The retrieved value of the variable as a double.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Attempts to open the specified control file in read mode using the fopen function. If the filename ends with a '-', the file is not opened.
  • Constructs the full variable name based on the variable name and array index provided.
  • Reads data from the control file, searching for the full variable name. If found, it sets the contain flag to 1 and breaks the loop.
  • Searches through the command-line arguments for the full variable name. If found, it sets the value and contain flag and breaks the loop.
  • Closes the control file if opened.
  • If the variable is not found, it sets the value to the default value provided or throws an error if no default value is provided.
  • Writes the variable name and its value to the log.
  • Copies the retrieved value to the value parameter if it is not NULL.
  • Returns the retrieved value as a double after converting it from a string using the atof function.
Note
This function assumes that the variable names and their values in the control file or command-line arguments are separated by whitespace.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 10955 of file mptrac.c.

10962 {
10963
10964 FILE *in = NULL;
10965
10966 char fullname1[LEN], fullname2[LEN], rval[LEN];
10967
10968 int contain = 0, i;
10969
10970 /* Open file... */
10971 if (filename[strlen(filename) - 1] != '-')
10972 if (!(in = fopen(filename, "r")))
10973 ERRMSG("Cannot open file!");
10974
10975 /* Set full variable name... */
10976 if (arridx >= 0) {
10977 sprintf(fullname1, "%s[%d]", varname, arridx);
10978 sprintf(fullname2, "%s[*]", varname);
10979 } else {
10980 sprintf(fullname1, "%s", varname);
10981 sprintf(fullname2, "%s", varname);
10982 }
10983
10984 /* Read data... */
10985 if (in != NULL) {
10986 char dummy[LEN], line[LEN], rvarname[LEN];
10987 while (fgets(line, LEN, in)) {
10988 if (sscanf(line, "%4999s %4999s %4999s", rvarname, dummy, rval) == 3)
10989 if (strcasecmp(rvarname, fullname1) == 0 ||
10990 strcasecmp(rvarname, fullname2) == 0) {
10991 contain = 1;
10992 break;
10993 }
10994 }
10995 }
10996 for (i = 1; i < argc - 1; i++)
10997 if (strcasecmp(argv[i], fullname1) == 0 ||
10998 strcasecmp(argv[i], fullname2) == 0) {
10999 sprintf(rval, "%s", argv[i + 1]);
11000 contain = 1;
11001 break;
11002 }
11003
11004 /* Close file... */
11005 if (in != NULL)
11006 fclose(in);
11007
11008 /* Check for missing variables... */
11009 if (!contain) {
11010 if (strlen(defvalue) > 0)
11011 sprintf(rval, "%s", defvalue);
11012 else
11013 ERRMSG("Missing variable %s!\n", fullname1);
11014 }
11015
11016 /* Write info... */
11017 LOG(1, "%s = %s", fullname1, rval);
11018
11019 /* Return values... */
11020 if (value != NULL)
11021 sprintf(value, "%s", rval);
11022 return atof(rval);
11023}

◆ sedi()

double sedi ( const double  p,
const double  T,
const double  rp,
const double  rhop 
)

Calculates the sedimentation velocity of a particle in air.

This function calculates the sedimentation velocity of a particle in air using the given parameters.

Parameters
pThe atmospheric pressure [hPa].
TThe temperature [K].
rpThe radius of the particle [microns].
rhopThe density of the particle [kg/m^3].
Returns
The sedimentation velocity of the particle [m/s].

The function performs the following steps:

  • Converts the radius of the particle from microns to meters.
  • Calculates the density of dry air using the given atmospheric pressure and temperature.
  • Calculates the dynamic viscosity of air using Sutherland's formula.
  • Calculates the thermal velocity of an air molecule using the given temperature.
  • Calculates the mean free path of an air molecule.
  • Computes the Knudsen number for air based on the ratio of mean free path to particle radius.
  • Applies the Cunningham slip-flow correction factor to account for particle size.
  • Computes the sedimentation velocity of the particle based on the difference in densities between the particle and air, incorporating the slip-flow correction.
Note
This function assumes that the ideal gas law and Stokes' law are applicable for calculating the sedimentation velocity of the particle.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11027 of file mptrac.c.

11031 {
11032
11033 /* Convert particle radius from microns to m... */
11034 const double rp_help = rp * 1e-6;
11035
11036 /* Density of dry air [kg / m^3]... */
11037 const double rho = RHO(p, T);
11038
11039 /* Dynamic viscosity of air [kg / (m s)]... */
11040 const double eta = 1.8325e-5 * (416.16 / (T + 120.)) * pow(T / 296.16, 1.5);
11041
11042 /* Thermal velocity of an air molecule [m / s]... */
11043 const double v = sqrt(8. * KB * T / (M_PI * 4.8096e-26));
11044
11045 /* Mean free path of an air molecule [m]... */
11046 const double lambda = 2. * eta / (rho * v);
11047
11048 /* Knudsen number for air (dimensionless)... */
11049 const double K = lambda / rp_help;
11050
11051 /* Cunningham slip-flow correction (dimensionless)... */
11052 const double G = 1. + K * (1.249 + 0.42 * exp(-0.87 / K));
11053
11054 /* Sedimentation velocity [m / s]... */
11055 return 2. * SQR(rp_help) * (rhop - rho) * G0 / (9. * eta) * G;
11056}
KB
#define KB
Boltzmann constant [kg m^2/(K s^2)].
Definition: mptrac.h:234

◆ spline()

void spline ( const double *  x,
const double *  y,
const int  n,
const double *  x2,
double *  y2,
const int  n2,
const int  method 
)

Performs spline interpolation or linear interpolation.

This function interpolates a set of data points using either cubic spline interpolation or linear interpolation, depending on the specified method.

Parameters
xThe array of x-coordinates of the data points.
yThe array of y-coordinates of the data points.
nThe number of data points.
x2The array of x-coordinates where interpolation is required.
y2The array to store the interpolated y-values.
n2The number of points to interpolate.
methodThe interpolation method: 1 for cubic spline, 0 for linear interpolation.

If the method is set to 1 (cubic spline interpolation):

  • The function initializes a cubic spline interpolator using GSL.
  • It interpolates the y-values at the specified x-coordinates using the spline.
  • The interpolated y-values are stored in the provided y2 array.

If the method is set to 0 (linear interpolation):

  • The function performs linear interpolation between adjacent data points.
  • It locates the interval where each interpolation point falls and calculates the interpolated y-value using linear interpolation.
  • The interpolated y-values are stored in the provided y2 array.
Note
The x-coordinates in both arrays (x and x2) must be sorted in ascending order.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11060 of file mptrac.c.

11067 {
11068
11069 /* Cubic spline interpolation... */
11070 if (method == 1) {
11071
11072 /* Allocate... */
11073 gsl_interp_accel *acc = gsl_interp_accel_alloc();
11074 gsl_spline *s = gsl_spline_alloc(gsl_interp_cspline, (size_t) n);
11075
11076 /* Interpolate profile... */
11077 gsl_spline_init(s, x, y, (size_t) n);
11078 for (int i = 0; i < n2; i++)
11079 if (x2[i] <= x[0])
11080 y2[i] = y[0];
11081 else if (x2[i] >= x[n - 1])
11082 y2[i] = y[n - 1];
11083 else
11084 y2[i] = gsl_spline_eval(s, x2[i], acc);
11085
11086 /* Free... */
11087 gsl_spline_free(s);
11088 gsl_interp_accel_free(acc);
11089 }
11090
11091 /* Linear interpolation... */
11092 else {
11093 for (int i = 0; i < n2; i++)
11094 if (x2[i] <= x[0])
11095 y2[i] = y[0];
11096 else if (x2[i] >= x[n - 1])
11097 y2[i] = y[n - 1];
11098 else {
11099 const int idx = locate_irr(x, n, x2[i]);
11100 y2[i] = LIN(x[idx], y[idx], x[idx + 1], y[idx + 1], x2[i]);
11101 }
11102 }
11103}
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ stddev()

float stddev ( const float *  data,
const int  n 
)

Calculates the standard deviation of a set of data.

This function calculates the standard deviation of a set of floating-point data values.

Parameters
dataPointer to the array of data values.
nNumber of data values in the array.
Returns
The standard deviation of the data values. If the number of data values is less than or equal to 0, returns 0.

The standard deviation is calculated using the formula:

\[ \sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n}} \]

where:

  • \( \sigma \) is the standard deviation,
  • \( x_i \) is each data value,
  • \( \bar{x} \) is the mean of the data values, and
  • \( n \) is the total number of data values.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11107 of file mptrac.c.

11109 {
11110
11111 if (n <= 0)
11112 return 0;
11113
11114 float mean = 0, var = 0;
11115
11116 for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
11117 mean += data[i];
11118 var += SQR(data[i]);
11119 }
11120
11121 var = var / (float) n - SQR(mean / (float) n);
11122
11123 return (var > 0 ? sqrtf(var) : 0);
11124}

◆ sza_calc()

double sza_calc ( const double  sec,
const double  lon,
const double  lat 
)

Calculates the solar zenith angle.

This function calculates the solar zenith angle, which is the angle between the zenith (straight up) and the line connecting the observer to the center of the sun.

Parameters
secSeconds elapsed since 2000-01-01T12:00Z.
lonObserver's longitude in degrees.
latObserver's latitude in degrees.
Returns
The solar zenith angle in radians.

The solar zenith angle is calculated based on the observer's position (longitude and latitude) and the time specified in seconds elapsed since 2000-01-01T12:00Z.

Note
This function assumes that the input longitude and latitude are given in degrees.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11128 of file mptrac.c.

11131 {
11132
11133 /* Number of days and fraction with respect to 2000-01-01T12:00Z... */
11134 const double D = sec / 86400 - 0.5;
11135
11136 /* Geocentric apparent ecliptic longitude [rad]... */
11137 const double g = DEG2RAD(357.529 + 0.98560028 * D);
11138 const double q = 280.459 + 0.98564736 * D;
11139 const double L = DEG2RAD(q + 1.915 * sin(g) + 0.020 * sin(2 * g));
11140
11141 /* Mean obliquity of the ecliptic [rad]... */
11142 const double e = DEG2RAD(23.439 - 0.00000036 * D);
11143
11144 /* Declination [rad]... */
11145 const double sindec = sin(e) * sin(L);
11146
11147 /* Right ascension [rad]... */
11148 const double ra = atan2(cos(e) * sin(L), cos(L));
11149
11150 /* Greenwich Mean Sidereal Time [h]... */
11151 const double GMST = 18.697374558 + 24.06570982441908 * D;
11152
11153 /* Local Sidereal Time [h]... */
11154 const double LST = GMST + lon / 15;
11155
11156 /* Hour angle [rad]... */
11157 const double h = LST / 12 * M_PI - ra;
11158
11159 /* Convert latitude... */
11160 const double lat_help = DEG2RAD(lat);
11161
11162 /* Return solar zenith angle [rad]... */
11163 return acos(sin(lat_help) * sindec +
11164 cos(lat_help) * sqrt(1 - SQR(sindec)) * cos(h));
11165}

◆ time2jsec()

void time2jsec ( const int  year,
const int  mon,
const int  day,
const int  hour,
const int  min,
const int  sec,
const double  remain,
double *  jsec 
)

Converts time components to seconds since January 1, 2000, 12:00:00 UTC.

This function calculates the number of seconds elapsed since January 1, 2000, 12:00:00 UTC, based on the provided year, month, day, hour, minute, and second. It also includes a fractional part to represent the remaining seconds.

Parameters
yearThe year.
monThe month (1-12).
dayThe day of the month (1-31).
hourThe hour of the day (0-23).
minThe minute (0-59).
secThe second (0-59).
remainThe fractional part of seconds.
jsecPointer to store the calculated number of seconds since January 1, 2000, 12:00:00 UTC.

The function calculates the time elapsed since January 1, 2000, 12:00:00 UTC, up to the specified time and includes any fractional seconds indicated by the "remain" parameter.

Note
The function uses the timegm function, which is similar to mktime but operates in UTC.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11169 of file mptrac.c.

11177 {
11178
11179 struct tm t0, t1;
11180
11181 t0.tm_year = 100;
11182 t0.tm_mon = 0;
11183 t0.tm_mday = 1;
11184 t0.tm_hour = 0;
11185 t0.tm_min = 0;
11186 t0.tm_sec = 0;
11187
11188 t1.tm_year = year - 1900;
11189 t1.tm_mon = mon - 1;
11190 t1.tm_mday = day;
11191 t1.tm_hour = hour;
11192 t1.tm_min = min;
11193 t1.tm_sec = sec;
11194
11195 *jsec = (double) timegm(&t1) - (double) timegm(&t0) + remain;
11196}

◆ timer()

void timer ( const char *  name,
const char *  group,
const int  output 
)

Measures and reports elapsed time for named and grouped timers.

The timer function measures elapsed time for a specified named timer and an optional group of timers, accumulating time statistics such as minimum, maximum, and mean elapsed times. It also provides an option to log the timing statistics to an output.

Parameters
nameA string representing the name of the timer.
groupA string representing the group to which the timer belongs.
outputAn integer flag indicating whether to report the timing statistics (non-zero to report).

The function keeps track of multiple timers and groups. When called, it:

  • Gets the current time and calculates the elapsed time since the last call.
  • Adds the elapsed time to the current timers' statistics.
  • Reports the statistics if the output parameter is non-zero.
  • Identifies the IDs of the next timer and group based on the provided name and group.
  • Checks if the name and group are new, and if so, initializes them.
  • Saves the starting time for the next measurement.
Note
The function uses OpenMP's omp_get_wtime() to get the current wall time.
The function maintains static arrays and variables to store timer names, groups, and statistics.
The maximum number of timers and groups is defined by the NTIMER macro.
Warning
If the number of timers or groups exceeds NTIMER, the function will trigger an error message.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11200 of file mptrac.c.

11203 {
11204
11205 static char names[NTIMER][100], groups[NTIMER][100];
11206
11207 static double rt_name[NTIMER], rt_group[NTIMER],
11208 rt_min[NTIMER], rt_max[NTIMER], dt, t0, t1;
11209
11210 static int iname = -1, igroup = -1, nname, ngroup, ct_name[NTIMER];
11211
11212 /* Get time... */
11213 t1 = omp_get_wtime();
11214 dt = t1 - t0;
11215
11216 /* Add elapsed time to current timers... */
11217 if (iname >= 0) {
11218 rt_name[iname] += dt;
11219 rt_min[iname] = (ct_name[iname] <= 0 ? dt : MIN(rt_min[iname], dt));
11220 rt_max[iname] = (ct_name[iname] <= 0 ? dt : MAX(rt_max[iname], dt));
11221 ct_name[iname]++;
11222 }
11223 if (igroup >= 0)
11224 rt_group[igroup] += t1 - t0;
11225
11226 /* Report timers... */
11227 if (output) {
11228 for (int i = 0; i < nname; i++)
11229 LOG(1, "TIMER_%s = %.3f s (min= %g s, mean= %g s,"
11230 " max= %g s, n= %d)", names[i], rt_name[i], rt_min[i],
11231 rt_name[i] / ct_name[i], rt_max[i], ct_name[i]);
11232 for (int i = 0; i < ngroup; i++)
11233 LOG(1, "TIMER_GROUP_%s = %.3f s", groups[i], rt_group[i]);
11234 double total = 0.0;
11235 for (int i = 0; i < nname; i++)
11236 total += rt_name[i];
11237 LOG(1, "TIMER_TOTAL = %.3f s", total);
11238 }
11239
11240 /* Identify IDs of next timer... */
11241 for (iname = 0; iname < nname; iname++)
11242 if (strcasecmp(name, names[iname]) == 0)
11243 break;
11244 for (igroup = 0; igroup < ngroup; igroup++)
11245 if (strcasecmp(group, groups[igroup]) == 0)
11246 break;
11247
11248 /* Check whether this is a new timer... */
11249 if (iname >= nname) {
11250 sprintf(names[iname], "%s", name);
11251 if ((++nname) >= NTIMER)
11252 ERRMSG("Too many timers!");
11253 }
11254
11255 /* Check whether this is a new group... */
11256 if (igroup >= ngroup) {
11257 sprintf(groups[igroup], "%s", group);
11258 if ((++ngroup) >= NTIMER)
11259 ERRMSG("Too many groups!");
11260 }
11261
11262 /* Save starting time... */
11263 t0 = t1;
11264}
NTIMER
#define NTIMER
Maximum number of timers.
Definition: mptrac.h:2065

◆ time_from_filename()

double time_from_filename ( const char *  filename,
const int  offset 
)

Extracts and converts a timestamp from a filename to Julian seconds.

The time_from_filename function parses a given filename to extract a timestamp and converts it to Julian seconds. The timestamp is expected to follow a specific format and position within the filename, defined by the offset parameter.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the filename containing the timestamp.
offsetAn integer indicating the position from the end of the filename where the timestamp starts.
Returns
The time in Julian seconds as a double.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Extracts the year, month, day, hour, and minute components of the timestamp from the filename using the given offset.
  • Validates the extracted components to ensure they represent a valid date and time.
  • Converts the validated date and time components to Julian seconds using the time2jsec function.
  • Returns the computed time in Julian seconds.
Note
The expected format of the timestamp in the filename is YYYY-MM-DD_HH-MM (e.g., "2023-05-27_14-45").
Warning
If the extracted components do not represent a valid date and time, the function will trigger an error message.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11268 of file mptrac.c.

11270 {
11271
11272 char tstr[10];
11273
11274 double t;
11275
11276 /* Get time from filename... */
11277 int len = (int) strlen(filename);
11278 sprintf(tstr, "%.4s", &filename[len - offset]);
11279 int year = atoi(tstr);
11280 sprintf(tstr, "%.2s", &filename[len - offset + 5]);
11281 int mon = atoi(tstr);
11282 sprintf(tstr, "%.2s", &filename[len - offset + 8]);
11283 int day = atoi(tstr);
11284 sprintf(tstr, "%.2s", &filename[len - offset + 11]);
11285 int hour = atoi(tstr);
11286 sprintf(tstr, "%.2s", &filename[len - offset + 14]);
11287 int min = atoi(tstr);
11288
11289 /* Check time... */
11290 if (year < 1900 || year > 2100 || mon < 1 || mon > 12 || day < 1
11291 || day > 31 || hour < 0 || hour > 23 || min < 0 || min > 59)
11292 ERRMSG("Cannot read time from filename!");
11293
11294 /* Convert time to Julian seconds... */
11295 time2jsec(year, mon, day, hour, min, 0, 0.0, &t);
11296
11297 /* Return time... */
11298 return t;
11299}

◆ tropo_weight()

double tropo_weight ( const clim_t *  clim,
const atm_t *  atm,
const int  ip 
)

Computes a weighting factor based on tropopause pressure.

This function calculates a weighting factor for a given pressure value in relation to the tropopause pressure. The weighting factor is determined as follows:

  • Returns 1 if the pressure is greater than a calculated upper limit.
  • Returns 0 if the pressure is less than a calculated lower limit.
  • Linearly interpolates between 1 and 0 within the range defined by the upper and lower limits.
Parameters
[in]climPointer to the climatology data structure.
[in]atmPointer to the atmospheric data structure.
[in]ipIndex of the pressure value to evaluate within the atmospheric data.
Returns
Weighting factor (double) in the range [0, 1].
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11303 of file mptrac.c.

11306 {
11307
11308 /* Get tropopause pressure... */
11309 const double pt = clim_tropo(clim, atm->time[ip], atm->lat[ip]);
11310
11311 /* Get pressure range... */
11312 const double p1 = pt * 0.866877899;
11313 const double p0 = pt / 0.866877899;
11314
11315 /* Get weighting factor... */
11316 if (atm->p[ip] > p0)
11317 return 1;
11318 else if (atm->p[ip] < p1)
11319 return 0;
11320 else
11321 return LIN(p0, 1.0, p1, 0.0, atm->p[ip]);
11322}

◆ write_atm_asc()

void write_atm_asc ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm,
const double  t 
)

Writes air parcel data to an ASCII file or gnuplot.

The write_atm_asc function writes the atmospheric data stored in the atm structure to an ASCII file specified by filename or to pipe to gnuplot if requested.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the file to write the data to.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.
tThe current time used for filtering and timestamping.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Sets the time interval for the output data based on the control parameters.
  • Checks if gnuplot output is requested and, if so, creates a pipe to gnuplot and sets up the plot.
  • If gnuplot output is not requested, creates an ASCII file for writing.
  • Writes the header information to the output file, including the description of each column.
  • Iterates over the particles in the atm structure, filtering by time if specified, and writes the data to the output file.
  • Closes the output file or gnuplot pipe.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

11369 ERRMSG("Cannot create file!");

11375 "# $2 = altitude [km]\n"
11376 "# $3 = longitude [deg]\n" "# $4 = latitude [deg]\n");
11377 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
11378 fprintf(out, "# $%i = %s [%s]\n", iq + 5, ctl->qnt_name[iq],
11379 ctl->qnt_unit[iq]);
11380 fprintf(out, "\n");
11381
11382 /* Write data... */
11383 for (int ip = 0; ip < atm->np; ip += ctl->atm_stride) {
11384
11385 /* Check time... */
11386 if (ctl->atm_filter == 2 && (atm->time[ip] < t0 || atm->time[ip] > t1))
11387 continue;
11388
11389 /* Write output... */
11390 fprintf(out, "%.2f %g %g %g", atm->time[ip], Z(atm->p[ip]),
11391 atm->lon[ip], atm->lat[ip]);
11392 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
11393 fprintf(out, " ");
11394 if (ctl->atm_filter == 1 && (atm->time[ip] < t0 || atm->time[ip] > t1))
11395 fprintf(out, ctl->qnt_format[iq], NAN);
11396 else
11397 fprintf(out, ctl->qnt_format[iq], atm->q[iq][ip]);
11398 }
11399 fprintf(out, "\n");
11400 }
11401
11402 /* Close file... */
11403 fclose(out);
11404}

◆ write_atm_bin()

void write_atm_bin ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm 
)

Writes air parcel data to a binary file.

The write_atm_bin function writes the air parcel data stored in the atm structure to a binary file specified by filename. The function includes versioning information and ensures that all relevant data arrays are written in a consistent binary format.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the file to write the data to.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Creates the binary file for writing. If the file cannot be created, it triggers an error message.
  • Writes a version number for the binary data format.
  • Writes the number of particles to the file.
  • Writes the time, pressure, longitude, and latitude arrays to the file.
  • Iterates over the quantities specified in the ctl structure and writes each quantity array to the file.
  • Writes a final flag to indicate the end of the binary data.
  • Closes the file.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

◆ write_atm_clams()

void write_atm_clams ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm 
)

Writes air parcel data to a NetCDF file in the CLaMS format.

The write_atm_clams function creates a NetCDF file and writes air parcel data into it. The data includes time, latitude, longitude, pressure, and other specified quantities. The function defines the dimensions and variables, sets global attributes, and writes the data to the file.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Creates the NetCDF file with the specified filename.
  • Defines the dimensions for time and the number of particles (NPARTS).
  • Defines variables for time, latitude, longitude, pressure, zeta, and other quantities.
  • Sets global attributes for the vertical coordinate name and model.
  • Writes the data into the NetCDF file.
  • Closes the NetCDF file after writing.
Author
Jan Clemens

◆ write_atm_clams_traj()

void write_atm_clams_traj ( const char *  dirname,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm,
const double  t 
)

Writes CLaMS trajectory data to a NetCDF file.

The write_atm_clams_traj function writes trajectory data for the CLaMS model to a NetCDF file. The file is created and populated with data including time, latitude, longitude, pressure, and other quantities. The function also handles the creation of a final initialization file at the last time step.

Parameters
dirnameA string representing the directory name where the file will be created.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.
tThe current time in seconds since a reference epoch.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Determines the start and stop times of the calculation.
  • Constructs the output filename based on the start and stop times.
  • Defines the hyperslab for the trajectory file.
  • Creates the NetCDF file if it's the first time step and defines dimensions and variables.
  • Writes the trajectory data to the NetCDF file.
  • At the last time step, creates an initialization file with the final data.
Author
Jan Clemens

Definition at line 11511 of file mptrac.c.

11516
11517 /* Global Counter... */

11542 year_start % 100, mon_start, day_start, hour_start,
11543 year_stop % 100, mon_stop, day_stop, hour_stop);
11544 LOG(1, "Write traj file: %s", filename_out);

11548 start[1] = 0;

11552 /* Create the file at the first timestep... */
11553 if (out_cnt == 0) {
11554
11555 /* Create file... */
11556 NC(nc_create(filename_out, NC_NETCDF4, &ncid));
11557
11558 /* Define dimensions... */
11559 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "time", NC_UNLIMITED, &tid));
11560 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "NPARTS", (size_t) atm->np, &pid));
11561 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "TMDT", 7, &cid));
11562 dim_ids[0] = tid;
11563 dim_ids[1] = pid;
11564
11565 /* Define variables and their attributes... */
11566 NC_DEF_VAR("time", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &tid, "Time",
11567 "seconds since 2000-01-01 00:00:00 UTC", ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11568 NC_DEF_VAR("LAT", NC_DOUBLE, 2, dim_ids, "Latitude", "deg",
11569 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11570 NC_DEF_VAR("LON", NC_DOUBLE, 2, dim_ids, "Longitude", "deg",
11571 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11572 NC_DEF_VAR("PRESS", NC_DOUBLE, 2, dim_ids, "Pressure", "hPa",
11573 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11574 NC_DEF_VAR("ZETA", NC_DOUBLE, 2, dim_ids, "Zeta", "K",
11575 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11576 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
11577 NC_DEF_VAR(ctl->qnt_name[iq], NC_DOUBLE, 2, dim_ids,
11578 ctl->qnt_name[iq], ctl->qnt_unit[iq],
11579 ctl->atm_nc_level, ctl->atm_nc_quant[iq]);
11580
11581 /* Define global attributes... */
11582 NC_PUT_ATT_GLOBAL("exp_VERTCOOR_name", "zeta");
11583 NC_PUT_ATT_GLOBAL("model", "MPTRAC");
11584
11585 /* End definitions... */
11586 NC(nc_enddef(ncid));
11587 NC(nc_close(ncid));
11588 }
11589
11590 /* Increment global counter to change hyperslap... */
11591 out_cnt++;
11592
11593 /* Open file... */
11594 NC(nc_open(filename_out, NC_WRITE, &ncid));
11595
11596 /* Write data... */
11597 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("time", atm->time, 1);
11598 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("LAT", atm->lat, 1);
11599 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("LON", atm->lon, 1);
11600 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("PRESS", atm->p, 1);
11601 if (ctl->advect_vert_coord == 1) {
11602 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("ZETA", atm->q[ctl->qnt_zeta], 1);
11603 } else if (ctl->qnt_zeta >= 0) {
11604 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("ZETA", atm->q[ctl->qnt_zeta_d], 1);
11605 }
11606 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
11607 NC_PUT_DOUBLE(ctl->qnt_name[iq], atm->q[iq], 1);
11608
11609 /* Close file... */
11610 NC(nc_close(ncid));
11611
11612 /* At the last time step create the init_fix_YYYYMMDDHH file... */
11613 if ((year == year_stop) && (mon == mon_stop)
11614 && (day == day_stop) && (hour == hour_stop)) {
11615
11616 /* Set filename... */
11617 char filename_init[2 * LEN] = "./init_fix_YYYYMMDDHH.nc";
11618 sprintf(filename_init, "%s/init_fix_%02d%02d%02d%02d.nc",
11619 dirname, year_stop % 100, mon_stop, day_stop, hour_stop);
11620 LOG(1, "Write init file: %s", filename_init);
11621
11622 /* Create file... */
11623 nc_create(filename_init, NC_NETCDF4, &ncid);
11624
11625 /* Define dimensions... */
11626 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "time", 1, &tid));
11627 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "NPARTS", (size_t) atm->np, &pid));
11628 dim_ids[0] = tid;
11629 dim_ids[1] = pid;
11630
11631 /* Define variables and their attributes... */
11632 NC_DEF_VAR("time", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &tid, "Time",
11633 "seconds since 2000-01-01 00:00:00 UTC", ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11634 NC_DEF_VAR("LAT", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &pid, "Latitude", "deg",
11635 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11636 NC_DEF_VAR("LON", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &pid, "Longitude", "deg",
11637 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11638 NC_DEF_VAR("PRESS", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &pid, "Pressure", "hPa",
11639 ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11640 NC_DEF_VAR("ZETA", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &pid, "Zeta", "K", ctl->atm_nc_level, 0);
11641 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
11642 NC_DEF_VAR(ctl->qnt_name[iq], NC_DOUBLE, 2, dim_ids,
11643 ctl->qnt_name[iq], ctl->qnt_unit[iq],
11644 ctl->atm_nc_level, ctl->atm_nc_quant[iq]);
11645
11646 /* Define global attributes... */
11647 NC_PUT_ATT_GLOBAL("exp_VERTCOOR_name", "zeta");
11648 NC_PUT_ATT_GLOBAL("model", "MPTRAC");
11649
11650 /* End definitions... */
11651 NC(nc_enddef(ncid));
11652
11653 /* Write data... */
11654 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("time", atm->time, 0);
11655 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("LAT", atm->lat, 0);
11656 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("LON", atm->lon, 0);
11657 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("PRESS", atm->p, 0);
11658 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("ZETA", atm->q[ctl->qnt_zeta_d], 0);
11659 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
11660 NC_PUT_DOUBLE(ctl->qnt_name[iq], atm->q[iq], 0);
11661
11662 /* Close file... */
11663 NC(nc_close(ncid));
11664 }
11665}
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ write_atm_nc()

void write_atm_nc ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm 
)

Writes air parcel data to a NetCDF file.

The write_atm_nc function creates a NetCDF file and writes air parcel data into it. The data includes time, pressure, longitude, latitude, and other specified quantities. The function defines the dimensions and variables, sets global attributes, and writes the data to the file.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Creates the NetCDF file with the specified filename.
  • Defines the dimension for the number of observations (obs).
  • Defines variables for time, pressure, longitude, latitude, and other quantities.
  • Sets global attributes for the feature type.
  • Writes the data into the NetCDF file.
  • Closes the NetCDF file after writing.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11669 of file mptrac.c.

11696 ctl->atm_nc_level, ctl->atm_nc_quant[iq]);

◆ write_csi()

void write_csi ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm,
const double  t 
)

Writes Critical Success Index (CSI) data to a file.

The write_csi function processes air parcel and observation data to calculate and write various verification statistics, including the Critical Success Index (CSI), to a specified output file at regular intervals. The statistics include measures such as the number of hits, misses, and false alarms, bias, probability of detection, false alarm rate, equitable threat score, and correlation coefficients.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.
tA double representing the current time.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Initializes resources and sets up the output file if the current time is the start time.
  • Reads observation data and kernel data if provided.
  • Sets grid box sizes and horizontal coordinates.
  • Allocates memory for mean and count arrays.
  • Loops over observations and model data to accumulate mean values and counts.
  • Analyzes the grid cells to calculate CSI and other statistics.
  • Writes the calculated statistics to the output file at specified intervals.
  • Frees allocated resources and closes the file when the processing is complete.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11718 of file mptrac.c.

11722 {
11723
11724 static FILE *out;
11725
11726 static double *modmean, *obsmean, *obsstd, *rt, *rz, *rlon, *rlat, *robs,
11727 *area, dlon, dlat, dz, x[NCSI], y[NCSI], obsstdn[NCSI], kz[EP], kw[EP];
11728
11729 static int *obscount, nobs, nk;
11730
11731 static int ct[NENS], cx[NENS], cy[NENS], cz[NENS], n[NENS];
11732
11733 const int ensemble = (ctl->nens > 0);
11734
11735 /* Set timer */
11736 SELECT_TIMER("WRITE_CSI", "OUTPUT", NVTX_WRITE);
11737
11738 /* Check quantities... */
11739 if (ctl->qnt_m < 0)
11740 ERRMSG("Need quantity mass!");
11741 if (ensemble) {
11742 if (ctl->qnt_ens < 0)
11743 ERRMSG("Missing ensemble IDs!");
11744 if (ctl->nens > NENS)
11745 ERRMSG("Too many ensembles!");
11746 }
11747
11748 /* Init... */
11749 if (t == ctl->t_start) {
11750
11751 /* Allocate.. */
11752 ALLOC(area, double,
11753 ctl->csi_ny);
11754 ALLOC(rt, double,
11755 NOBS);
11756 ALLOC(rz, double,
11757 NOBS);
11758 ALLOC(rlon, double,
11759 NOBS);
11760 ALLOC(rlat, double,
11761 NOBS);
11762 ALLOC(robs, double,
11763 NOBS);
11764
11765 /* Read observation data... */
11766 read_obs(ctl->csi_obsfile, ctl, rt, rz, rlon, rlat, robs, &nobs);
11767
11768 /* Read kernel data... */
11769 if (ctl->csi_kernel[0] != '-')
11770 read_kernel(ctl->csi_kernel, kz, kw, &nk);
11771
11772 /* Create new file... */
11773 LOG(1, "Write CSI%s data: %s", ensemble ? " ensemble" : "", filename);
11774 if (!(out = fopen(filename, "w")))
11775 ERRMSG("Cannot create file!");
11776
11777 /* Write header... */
11778 fprintf(out,
11779 "# $1 = time [s]\n"
11780 "# $2 = ensemble ID\n"
11781 "# $3 = number of hits (cx)\n"
11782 "# $4 = number of misses (cy)\n"
11783 "# $5 = number of false alarms (cz)\n"
11784 "# $6 = number of observations (cx + cy)\n"
11785 "# $7 = number of forecasts (cx + cz)\n"
11786 "# $8 = bias (%%)\n"
11787 "# $9 = POD (%%)\n"
11788 "# $10 = FAR (%%)\n"
11789 "# $11 = CSI (%%)\n"
11790 "# $12 = hits by random chance\n"
11791 "# $13 = ETS (%%)\n"
11792 "# $14 = Pearson R\n"
11793 "# $15 = Spearman R\n"
11794 "# $16 = mean error [kg/m²]\n"
11795 "# $17 = RMSE [kg/m²]\n"
11796 "# $18 = MAE [kg/m²]\n"
11797 "# $19 = log-likelihood\n" "# $20 = number of points\n\n");
11798
11799 /* Set grid box size... */
11800 dz = (ctl->csi_z1 - ctl->csi_z0) / ctl->csi_nz;
11801 dlon = (ctl->csi_lon1 - ctl->csi_lon0) / ctl->csi_nx;
11802 dlat = (ctl->csi_lat1 - ctl->csi_lat0) / ctl->csi_ny;
11803
11804 /* Set horizontal coordinates... */
11805 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->csi_ny; iy++) {
11806 const double lat = ctl->csi_lat0 + dlat * (iy + 0.5);
11807 area[iy] = dlat * dlon * SQR(RE * M_PI / 180.0) * cos(DEG2RAD(lat));
11808 }
11809 }
11810
11811 /* Set time interval... */
11812 const double t0 = t - 0.5 * ctl->dt_mod;
11813 const double t1 = t + 0.5 * ctl->dt_mod;
11814
11815 /* Allocate... */
11816 int grid_size = ctl->csi_nx * ctl->csi_ny * ctl->csi_nz;
11817 ALLOC(modmean, double,
11818 (ensemble ? ctl->nens : 1) * grid_size);
11819 ALLOC(obsmean, double,
11820 grid_size);
11821 ALLOC(obscount, int,
11822 grid_size);
11823 ALLOC(obsstd, double,
11824 grid_size);
11825
11826 /* Init... */
11827 for (int i = 0; i < (ensemble ? ctl->nens : 1); i++)
11828 ct[i] = cx[i] = cy[i] = cz[i] = n[i] = 0;
11829
11830 /* Loop over observations... */
11831 for (int i = 0; i < nobs; i++) {
11832 if (rt[i] < t0 || rt[i] >= t1 || !isfinite(robs[i]))
11833 continue;
11834
11835 /* Calculate indices... */
11836 const int ix = (int) ((rlon[i] - ctl->csi_lon0) / dlon);
11837 const int iy = (int) ((rlat[i] - ctl->csi_lat0) / dlat);
11838 const int iz = (int) ((rz[i] - ctl->csi_z0) / dz);
11839 if (ix < 0 || ix >= ctl->csi_nx || iy < 0 || iy >= ctl->csi_ny || iz < 0
11840 || iz >= ctl->csi_nz)
11841 continue;
11842
11843 /* Get mean observation index... */
11844 const int idx = ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->csi_ny, iz, ctl->csi_nz);
11845 obsmean[idx] += robs[i];
11846 obsstd[idx] += SQR(robs[i]);
11847 obscount[idx]++;
11848 }
11849
11850 /* Analyze model data... */
11851 for (int ip = 0; ip < atm->np; ip++) {
11852
11853 /* Check time... */
11854 if (atm->time[ip] < t0 || atm->time[ip] > t1)
11855 continue;
11856
11857 /* Get ensemble ID... */
11858 int ens_id = ensemble ? (int) atm->q[ctl->qnt_ens][ip] : 0;
11859 if (ens_id < 0 || ens_id >= (ensemble ? ctl->nens : 1))
11860 ERRMSG("Ensemble ID out of range!");
11861
11862 /* Get indices... */
11863 const int ix = (int) ((atm->lon[ip] - ctl->csi_lon0) / dlon);
11864 const int iy = (int) ((atm->lat[ip] - ctl->csi_lat0) / dlat);
11865 const int iz = (int) ((Z(atm->p[ip]) - ctl->csi_z0) / dz);
11866 if (ix < 0 || ix >= ctl->csi_nx || iy < 0 || iy >= ctl->csi_ny || iz < 0
11867 || iz >= ctl->csi_nz)
11868 continue;
11869
11870 /* Get total mass in grid cell... */
11871 const int idx =
11872 ens_id * grid_size + ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->csi_ny, iz, ctl->csi_nz);
11873 modmean[idx] +=
11874 kernel_weight(kz, kw, nk, atm->p[ip]) * atm->q[ctl->qnt_m][ip];
11875 }
11876 for (int e = 0; e < (ensemble ? ctl->nens : 1); e++) {
11877 /* Analyze all grid cells... */
11878 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->csi_nx; ix++)
11879 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->csi_ny; iy++)
11880 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->csi_nz; iz++) {
11881
11882 /* Calculate mean observation index... */
11883 const int idx = ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->csi_ny, iz, ctl->csi_nz);
11884 if (e == 0)
11885 if (obscount[idx]) {
11886 obsmean[idx] /= obscount[idx];
11887 obsstd[idx] =
11888 sqrt(obsstd[idx] / obscount[idx] - SQR(obsmean[idx]));
11889 }
11890
11891 /* Calculate model mean per ensemble... */
11892 const int midx = e * grid_size + idx;
11893 if (modmean[midx] > 0)
11894 modmean[midx] /= (1e6 * area[iy]);
11895
11896 /* Check number of observations... */
11897 if (obscount[idx]) {
11898
11899 /* Calculate CSI... */
11900 ct[e]++;
11901 if (obsmean[idx] >= ctl->csi_obsmin
11902 && modmean[midx] >= ctl->csi_modmin)
11903 cx[e]++;
11904 else if (obsmean[idx] >= ctl->csi_obsmin)
11905 cy[e]++;
11906 else if (modmean[midx] >= ctl->csi_modmin)
11907 cz[e]++;
11908
11909 /* Save data for other verification statistics... */
11910 if (obsmean[idx] >= ctl->csi_obsmin
11911 || modmean[midx] >= ctl->csi_modmin) {
11912 x[n[e]] = modmean[midx];
11913 y[n[e]] = obsmean[idx];
11914 if (modmean[midx] >= ctl->csi_modmin)
11915 obsstdn[n[e]] = obsstd[idx];
11916 if ((++n[e]) >= NCSI)
11917 ERRMSG("Too many points for statistics!");
11918 }
11919 }
11920 }
11921 /* Write output... */
11922 if (fmod(t, ctl->csi_dt_out) == 0) {
11923
11924 if (n[e] == 0)
11925 continue;
11926
11927 /* Calculate verification statistics
11928 (https://www.cawcr.gov.au/projects/verification/) ... */
11929 static double work[2 * NCSI], work2[2 * NCSI];
11930 const int n_obs = cx[e] + cy[e];
11931 const int n_for = cx[e] + cz[e];
11932 const double cx_rd = (ct[e] > 0) ? (1. * n_obs * n_for) / ct[e] : NAN;
11933 const double bias = (n_obs > 0) ? 100. * n_for / n_obs : NAN;
11934 const double pod = (n_obs > 0) ? 100. * cx[e] / n_obs : NAN;
11935 const double far = (n_for > 0) ? 100. * cz[e] / n_for : NAN;
11936 const double csi =
11937 (cx[e] + cy[e] + cz[e] >
11938 0) ? 100. * cx[e] / (cx[e] + cy[e] + cz[e]) : NAN;
11939 const double ets =
11940 (cx[e] + cy[e] + cz[e] - cx_rd >
11941 0) ? 100. * (cx[e] - cx_rd) / (cx[e] + cy[e] + cz[e] - cx_rd) : NAN;
11942 const double rho_p = gsl_stats_correlation(x, 1, y, 1, (size_t) n[e]);
11943 const double rho_s =
11944 gsl_stats_spearman(x, 1, y, 1, (size_t) n[e], work);
11945 for (int i = 0; i < n[e]; i++) {
11946 work[i] = x[i] - y[i];
11947 work2[i] = (obsstdn[i] != 0) ? work[i] / obsstdn[i] : 0;
11948 }
11949 const double mean = gsl_stats_mean(work, 1, (size_t) n[e]);
11950 const double rmse =
11951 gsl_stats_sd_with_fixed_mean(work, 1, (size_t) n[e], 0.0);
11952 const double absdev = gsl_stats_absdev_m(work, 1, (size_t) n[e], 0.0);
11953 const double loglikelihood =
11954 gsl_stats_tss_m(work2, 1, (size_t) n[e], 0.0) * -0.5;
11955
11956 /* Write... */
11957 fprintf(out,
11958 "%.2f %d %d %d %d %d %d %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %d\n",
11959 t, ensemble ? e : -999, cx[e], cy[e], cz[e], n_obs, n_for, bias,
11960 pod, far, csi, cx_rd, ets, rho_p, rho_s, mean, rmse, absdev,
11961 loglikelihood, n[e]);
11962
11963 /* Set counters to zero... */
11964 for (int i = 0; i < n[e]; i++)
11965 work[i] = work2[i] = x[i] = y[i] = obsstdn[i] = 0;
11966 ct[e] = cx[e] = cy[e] = cz[e] = n[e] = 0;
11967 }
11968 }
11969 /* Free... */
11970 free(modmean);
11971 free(obsmean);
11972 free(obscount);
11973 free(obsstd);
11974
11975 /* Finalize... */
11976 if (t == ctl->t_stop) {
11977
11978 /* Close output file... */
11979 fclose(out);
11980
11981 /* Free... */
11982 free(area);
11983 free(rt);
11984 free(rz);
11985 free(rlon);
11986 free(rlat);
11987 free(robs);
11988 }
11989}
read_obs
void read_obs(const char *filename, const ctl_t *ctl, double *rt, double *rz, double *rlon, double *rlat, double *robs, int *nobs)
Reads observation data from a file and stores it in arrays.

Reads kernel function data from a file and populates the provided arrays.

double kernel_weight(const double kz[EP], const double kw[EP], const int nk, const double p)
Calculates the kernel weight based on altitude and given kernel data.

NENS
#define NENS
Maximum number of data points for ensemble analysis.
Definition: mptrac.h:323

#define NCSI

Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ write_ens()

void write_ens ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const atm_t *  atm,
const double  t 
)

Writes ensemble data to a file.

The write_ens function processes air parcel data to calculate ensemble means and standard deviations for various quantities and writes them to a specified output file. It handles ensemble members and calculates statistics such as means and standard deviations for each ensemble, along with latitude, longitude, altitude, and time information.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.
tA double representing the current time.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Initializes resources and sets up necessary variables.
  • Sets a time interval for processing data.
  • Loops over air parcels to accumulate means and standard deviations for each ensemble member.
  • Creates an output file and writes header information.
  • Writes ensemble data, including time, altitude, latitude, longitude, means, standard deviations, and the number of members.
  • Closes the output file.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 11993 of file mptrac.c.

11997 {
11998
11999 static FILE *out;
12000
12001 static double dummy, lat, lon, qm[NQ][NENS], qs[NQ][NENS], xm[NENS][3],
12002 x[3], zm[NENS];
12003
12004 static int n[NENS];
12005
12006 /* Set timer... */
12007 SELECT_TIMER("WRITE_ENS", "OUTPUT", NVTX_WRITE);
12008
12009 /* Check quantities... */
12010 if (ctl->qnt_ens < 0)
12011 ERRMSG("Missing ensemble IDs!");
12012
12013 /* Set time interval... */
12014 const double t0 = t - 0.5 * ctl->dt_mod;
12015 const double t1 = t + 0.5 * ctl->dt_mod;
12016
12017 /* Init... */
12018 for (int i = 0; i < NENS; i++) {
12019 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
12020 qm[iq][i] = qs[iq][i] = 0;
12021 xm[i][0] = xm[i][1] = xm[i][2] = zm[i] = 0;
12022 n[i] = 0;
12023 }
12024
12025 /* Loop over air parcels... */
12026 for (int ip = 0; ip < atm->np; ip++) {
12027
12028 /* Check time... */
12029 if (atm->time[ip] < t0 || atm->time[ip] > t1)
12030 continue;
12031
12032 /* Check ensemble ID... */
12033 if (atm->q[ctl->qnt_ens][ip] < 0 || atm->q[ctl->qnt_ens][ip] >= NENS)
12034 ERRMSG("Ensemble ID is out of range!");
12035
12036 /* Get means... */
12037 geo2cart(0, atm->lon[ip], atm->lat[ip], x);
12038 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12039 qm[iq][ctl->qnt_ens] += atm->q[iq][ip];
12040 qs[iq][ctl->qnt_ens] += SQR(atm->q[iq][ip]);
12041 }
12042 xm[ctl->qnt_ens][0] += x[0];
12043 xm[ctl->qnt_ens][1] += x[1];
12044 xm[ctl->qnt_ens][2] += x[2];
12045 zm[ctl->qnt_ens] += Z(atm->p[ip]);
12046 n[ctl->qnt_ens]++;
12047 }
12048
12049 /* Create file... */
12050 LOG(1, "Write ensemble data: %s", filename);
12051 if (!(out = fopen(filename, "w")))
12052 ERRMSG("Cannot create file!");
12053
12054 /* Write header... */
12055 fprintf(out,
12056 "# $1 = time [s]\n"
12057 "# $2 = altitude [km]\n"
12058 "# $3 = longitude [deg]\n" "# $4 = latitude [deg]\n");
12059 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
12060 fprintf(out, "# $%d = %s (mean) [%s]\n", 5 + iq,
12061 ctl->qnt_name[iq], ctl->qnt_unit[iq]);
12062 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
12063 fprintf(out, "# $%d = %s (sigma) [%s]\n", 5 + ctl->nq + iq,
12064 ctl->qnt_name[iq], ctl->qnt_unit[iq]);
12065 fprintf(out, "# $%d = number of members\n\n", 5 + 2 * ctl->nq);
12066
12067 /* Write data... */
12068 for (int i = 0; i < NENS; i++)
12069 if (n[i] > 0) {
12070 cart2geo(xm[i], &dummy, &lon, &lat);
12071 fprintf(out, "%.2f %g %g %g", t, zm[i] / n[i], lon, lat);
12072 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12073 fprintf(out, " ");
12074 fprintf(out, ctl->qnt_format[iq], qm[iq][i] / n[i]);
12075 }
12076 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12077 fprintf(out, " ");
12078 double var = qs[iq][i] / n[i] - SQR(qm[iq][i] / n[i]);
12079 fprintf(out, ctl->qnt_format[iq], (var > 0 ? sqrt(var) : 0));
12080 }
12081 fprintf(out, " %d\n", n[i]);
12082 }
12083
12084 /* Close file... */
12085 fclose(out);
12086}
cart2geo
void cart2geo(const double *x, double *z, double *lon, double *lat)
State variables of cuRAND random number generator.
Definition: mptrac.c:74
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ write_grid()

void write_grid ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met0,
met_t *  met1,
const atm_t *  atm,
const double  t 
)

Writes grid data to a file in ASCII or netCDF format.

The write_grid function processes air parcel data to calculate various grid-based statistics such as column density, mean, and standard deviation for specified quantities. It then writes this data to a specified output file either in ASCII or netCDF format based on the configuration parameters provided in the ctl structure.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
met0A pointer to a met_t structure containing meteorological data for the initial time step.
met1A pointer to a met_t structure containing meteorological data for the final time step.
atmA pointer to an atm_t structure containing atmospheric data.
tA double representing the current time.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Initializes resources and sets up necessary variables.
  • Reads kernel data if it is specified in the control parameters.
  • Allocates memory for various arrays to store grid data.
  • Determines the grid box size and sets up vertical and horizontal coordinates.
  • Sets a time interval for output data processing.
  • Calculates grid box indices for atmospheric model data.
  • Averages data within each grid box.
  • Calculates column density and volume mixing ratio.
  • Writes data to the output file either in ASCII or netCDF format based on the specified grid_type in the control parameters.
  • Frees allocated memory.
Note
The function supports parallel processing using OpenMP for certain computational tasks to improve performance.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 12090 of file mptrac.c.

12096 {
12097
12098 static double kz[EP], kw[EP];
12099
12100 static int nk;
12101
12102 double *cd, *mean[NQ], *sigma[NQ], *vmr_impl, *z, *lon, *lat, *area, *press;
12103
12104 int *ixs, *iys, *izs, *np;
12105
12106 /* Set timer... */
12107 SELECT_TIMER("WRITE_GRID", "OUTPUT", NVTX_WRITE);
12108
12109 /* Write info... */
12110 LOG(1, "Write grid data: %s", filename);
12111
12112 /* Init... */
12113 if (t == ctl->t_start) {
12114
12115 /* Read kernel data... */
12116 if (ctl->grid_kernel[0] != '-')
12117 read_kernel(ctl->grid_kernel, kz, kw, &nk);
12118 }
12119
12120 /* Allocate... */
12121 ALLOC(cd, double,
12122 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12123 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12124 ALLOC(mean[iq], double,
12125 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12126 ALLOC(sigma[iq], double,
12127 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12128 }
12129 ALLOC(vmr_impl, double,
12130 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12131 ALLOC(z, double,
12132 ctl->grid_nz);
12133 ALLOC(lon, double,
12134 ctl->grid_nx);
12135 ALLOC(lat, double,
12136 ctl->grid_ny);
12137 ALLOC(area, double,
12138 ctl->grid_ny);
12139 ALLOC(press, double,
12140 ctl->grid_nz);
12141 ALLOC(np, int,
12142 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12143 ALLOC(ixs, int,
12144 atm->np);
12145 ALLOC(iys, int,
12146 atm->np);
12147 ALLOC(izs, int,
12148 atm->np);
12149
12150 /* Set grid box size... */
12151 const double dz = (ctl->grid_z1 - ctl->grid_z0) / ctl->grid_nz;
12152 const double dlon = (ctl->grid_lon1 - ctl->grid_lon0) / ctl->grid_nx;
12153 const double dlat = (ctl->grid_lat1 - ctl->grid_lat0) / ctl->grid_ny;
12154
12155 /* Set vertical coordinates... */
12156#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
12157 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++) {
12158 z[iz] = ctl->grid_z0 + dz * (iz + 0.5);
12159 press[iz] = P(z[iz]);
12160 }
12161
12162 /* Set horizontal coordinates... */
12163 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12164 lon[ix] = ctl->grid_lon0 + dlon * (ix + 0.5);
12165#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
12166 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++) {
12167 lat[iy] = ctl->grid_lat0 + dlat * (iy + 0.5);
12168 area[iy] = dlat * dlon * SQR(RE * M_PI / 180.) * cos(DEG2RAD(lat[iy]));
12169 }
12170
12171 /* Set time interval for output... */
12172 const double t0 = t - 0.5 * ctl->dt_mod;
12173 const double t1 = t + 0.5 * ctl->dt_mod;
12174
12175 /* Get grid box indices... */
12176#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
12177 for (int ip = 0; ip < atm->np; ip++) {
12178 ixs[ip] = (int) ((atm->lon[ip] - ctl->grid_lon0) / dlon);
12179 iys[ip] = (int) ((atm->lat[ip] - ctl->grid_lat0) / dlat);
12180 izs[ip] = (int) ((Z(atm->p[ip]) - ctl->grid_z0) / dz);
12181 if (atm->time[ip] < t0 || atm->time[ip] > t1
12182 || ixs[ip] < 0 || ixs[ip] >= ctl->grid_nx
12183 || iys[ip] < 0 || iys[ip] >= ctl->grid_ny
12184 || izs[ip] < 0 || izs[ip] >= ctl->grid_nz)
12185 izs[ip] = -1;
12186 }
12187
12188 /* Average data... */
12189 for (int ip = 0; ip < atm->np; ip++)
12190 if (izs[ip] >= 0) {
12191 const int idx =
12192 ARRAY_3D(ixs[ip], iys[ip], ctl->grid_ny, izs[ip], ctl->grid_nz);
12193 const double kernel = kernel_weight(kz, kw, nk, atm->p[ip]);
12194 np[idx]++;
12195 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12196 mean[iq][idx] += kernel * atm->q[iq][ip];
12197 sigma[iq][idx] += SQR(kernel * atm->q[iq][ip]);
12198 }
12199 }
12200
12201 /* Calculate column density and volume mixing ratio... */
12202#pragma omp parallel for default(shared)
12203 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12204 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++)
12205 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++) {
12206
12207 /* Get grid index... */
12208 const int idx = ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz);
12209
12210 /* Calculate column density... */
12211 cd[idx] = NAN;
12212 if (ctl->qnt_m >= 0)
12213 cd[idx] = mean[ctl->qnt_m][idx] / (1e6 * area[iy]);
12214
12215 /* Calculate volume mixing ratio (implicit)... */
12216 vmr_impl[idx] = NAN;
12217 if (ctl->qnt_m >= 0 && ctl->molmass > 0 && met0 != NULL
12218 && met1 != NULL) {
12219 vmr_impl[idx] = 0;
12220 if (mean[ctl->qnt_m][idx] > 0) {
12221
12222 /* Get temperature... */
12223 double temp;
12224 INTPOL_INIT;
12225 intpol_met_time_3d(met0, met0->t, met1, met1->t, t, press[iz],
12226 lon[ix], lat[iy], &temp, ci, cw, 1);
12227
12228 /* Calculate volume mixing ratio... */
12229 vmr_impl[idx] =
12230 MA / ctl->molmass * cd[idx] / (RHO(press[iz], temp) * dz * 1e3);
12231 }
12232 }
12233
12234 /* Calculate mean... */
12235 if (np[idx] > 0)
12236 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12237 mean[iq][idx] /= np[idx];
12238 const double var = sigma[iq][idx] / np[idx] - SQR(mean[iq][idx]);
12239 sigma[iq][idx] = (var > 0 ? sqrt(var) : 0);
12240 } else
12241 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12242 mean[iq][idx] = NAN;
12243 sigma[iq][idx] = NAN;
12244 }
12245 }
12246
12247 /* Write ASCII data... */
12248 if (ctl->grid_type == 0)
12249 write_grid_asc(filename, ctl, cd, mean, sigma, vmr_impl,
12250 t, z, lon, lat, area, dz, np);
12251
12252 /* Write netCDF data... */
12253 else if (ctl->grid_type == 1)
12254 write_grid_nc(filename, ctl, cd, mean, sigma, vmr_impl,
12255 t, z, lon, lat, area, dz, np);
12256
12257 /* Error message... */
12258 else
12259 ERRMSG("Grid data format GRID_TYPE unknown!");
12260
12261 /* Free... */
12262 free(cd);
12263 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12264 free(mean[iq]);
12265 free(sigma[iq]);
12266 }
12267 free(vmr_impl);
12268 free(z);
12269 free(lon);
12270 free(lat);
12271 free(area);
12272 free(press);
12273 free(np);
12274 free(ixs);
12275 free(iys);
12276 free(izs);
12277}
write_grid_asc
void write_grid_asc(const char *filename, const ctl_t *ctl, const double *cd, double *mean[NQ], double *sigma[NQ], const double *vmr_impl, const double t, const double *z, const double *lon, const double *lat, const double *area, const double dz, const int *np)
Writes grid data to an ASCII file.
Definition: mptrac.c:12281
write_grid_nc
void write_grid_nc(const char *filename, const ctl_t *ctl, const double *cd, double *mean[NQ], double *sigma[NQ], const double *vmr_impl, const double t, const double *z, const double *lon, const double *lat, const double *area, const double dz, const int *np)
Writes grid data to a NetCDF file.
Definition: mptrac.c:12385
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ write_grid_asc()

void write_grid_asc ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const double *  cd,
double *  mean[NQ],
double *  sigma[NQ],
const double *  vmr_impl,
const double  t,
const double *  z,
const double *  lon,
const double *  lat,
const double *  area,
const double  dz,
const int *  np 
)

Writes grid data to an ASCII file.

The write_grid_asc function writes gridded air parcel data, including column density, mean and standard deviation for specified quantities, and volume mixing ratio (if available), to an ASCII file. The function also supports writing gnuplot commands to generate plots if requested in the control parameters.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
cdAn array of doubles representing column density values.
meanAn array of arrays of doubles representing the mean values for specified quantities.
sigmaAn array of arrays of doubles representing the standard deviation values for specified quantities.
vmr_implAn array of doubles representing the volume mixing ratio (implicit) values.
tA double representing the current time.
zAn array of doubles representing vertical coordinates (altitude).
lonAn array of doubles representing longitudinal coordinates.
latAn array of doubles representing latitudinal coordinates.
areaAn array of doubles representing surface area values.
dzA double representing the layer depth.
npAn array of integers representing the number of particles.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Checks if gnuplot output is requested in the control parameters and sets up a gnuplot pipe if needed.
  • If gnuplot output is requested, sets the plot filename and time string, and dumps gnuplot file contents to the pipe.
  • Otherwise, creates the output file for writing in ASCII format.
  • Writes the header information to the output file, including column labels.
  • Writes the grid data to the output file, including time, altitude, coordinates, surface area, layer depth, column density, volume mixing ratio, number of particles, mean values for specified quantities, and standard deviation values if requested.
  • Closes the output file.
Note
The function supports writing gnuplot commands to generate plots if requested in the control parameters. It also supports writing mean and standard deviation values for specified quantities if requested.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 12281 of file mptrac.c.

12294 {
12295
12296 FILE *out;
12297
12298 /* Check if gnuplot output is requested... */
12299 if (ctl->grid_gpfile[0] != '-') {
12300
12301 /* Create gnuplot pipe... */
12302 if (!(out = popen("gnuplot", "w")))
12303 ERRMSG("Cannot create pipe to gnuplot!");
12304
12305 /* Set plot filename... */
12306 fprintf(out, "set out \"%s.png\"\n", filename);
12307
12308 /* Set time string... */
12309 double r;
12310 int year, mon, day, hour, min, sec;
12311 jsec2time(t, &year, &mon, &day, &hour, &min, &sec, &r);
12312 fprintf(out, "timestr=\"%d-%02d-%02d, %02d:%02d UTC\"\n",
12313 year, mon, day, hour, min);
12314
12315 /* Dump gnuplot file to pipe... */
12316 FILE *in;
12317 char line[LEN];
12318 if (!(in = fopen(ctl->grid_gpfile, "r")))
12319 ERRMSG("Cannot open file!");
12320 while (fgets(line, LEN, in))
12321 fprintf(out, "%s", line);
12322 fclose(in);
12323 }
12324
12325 else {
12326
12327 /* Create file... */
12328 if (!(out = fopen(filename, "w")))
12329 ERRMSG("Cannot create file!");
12330 }
12331
12332 /* Write header... */
12333 fprintf(out,
12334 "# $1 = time [s]\n"
12335 "# $2 = altitude [km]\n"
12336 "# $3 = longitude [deg]\n"
12337 "# $4 = latitude [deg]\n"
12338 "# $5 = surface area [km^2]\n"
12339 "# $6 = layer depth [km]\n"
12340 "# $7 = column density (implicit) [kg/m^2]\n"
12341 "# $8 = volume mixing ratio (implicit) [ppv]\n"
12342 "# $9 = number of particles [1]\n");
12343 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
12344 fprintf(out, "# $%i = %s (mean) [%s]\n", 10 + iq, ctl->qnt_name[iq],
12345 ctl->qnt_unit[iq]);
12346 if (ctl->grid_stddev)
12347 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++)
12348 fprintf(out, "# $%i = %s (stddev) [%s]\n", 10 + ctl->nq + iq,
12349 ctl->qnt_name[iq], ctl->qnt_unit[iq]);
12350 fprintf(out, "\n");
12351
12352 /* Write data... */
12353 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++) {
12354 if (ix > 0 && ctl->grid_ny > 1 && !ctl->grid_sparse)
12355 fprintf(out, "\n");
12356 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++) {
12357 if (iy > 0 && ctl->grid_nz > 1 && !ctl->grid_sparse)
12358 fprintf(out, "\n");
12359 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++) {
12360 int idx = ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz);
12361 if (!ctl->grid_sparse || vmr_impl[idx] > 0) {
12362 fprintf(out, "%.2f %g %g %g %g %g %g %g %d", t, z[iz], lon[ix],
12363 lat[iy], area[iy], dz, cd[idx], vmr_impl[idx], np[idx]);
12364 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12365 fprintf(out, " ");
12366 fprintf(out, ctl->qnt_format[iq], mean[iq][idx]);
12367 }
12368 if (ctl->grid_stddev)
12369 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12370 fprintf(out, " ");
12371 fprintf(out, ctl->qnt_format[iq], sigma[iq][idx]);
12372 }
12373 fprintf(out, "\n");
12374 }
12375 }
12376 }
12377 }
12378
12379 /* Close file... */
12380 fclose(out);
12381}
Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ write_grid_nc()

void write_grid_nc ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
const double *  cd,
double *  mean[NQ],
double *  sigma[NQ],
const double *  vmr_impl,
const double  t,
const double *  z,
const double *  lon,
const double *  lat,
const double *  area,
const double  dz,
const int *  np 
)

Writes grid data to a NetCDF file.

The write_grid_nc function writes gridded air parcel data, including column density, mean and standard deviation for specified quantities, and volume mixing ratio (if available), to a NetCDF file. NetCDF is a self-describing, machine-independent data format for storing scientific data.

Parameters
filenameA string representing the name of the output file.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure containing control parameters.
cdAn array of doubles representing column density values.
meanAn array of arrays of doubles representing the mean values for specified quantities.
sigmaAn array of arrays of doubles representing the standard deviation values for specified quantities.
vmr_implAn array of doubles representing the volume mixing ratio (implicit) values.
tA double representing the current time.
zAn array of doubles representing vertical coordinates (altitude).
lonAn array of doubles representing longitudinal coordinates.
latAn array of doubles representing latitudinal coordinates.
areaAn array of doubles representing surface area values.
dzA double representing the layer depth.
npAn array of integers representing the number of particles.

The function performs the following steps:

  • Allocates memory for temporary arrays required for writing data.
  • Creates a NetCDF file with the specified filename.
  • Defines dimensions and variables in the NetCDF file, along with their attributes.
  • Writes the data arrays to the NetCDF file.
  • Closes the NetCDF file.
  • Frees allocated memory.
Note
NetCDF files are commonly used in scientific computing and can be accessed by various programming languages and software packages. Additionally, the function supports writing mean and standard deviation values for specified quantities if requested.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 12385 of file mptrac.c.

12398 {
12399
12400 char longname[2 * LEN], varname[2 * LEN];
12401
12402 double *help;
12403
12404 int *help2, ncid, dimid[10], varid;
12405
12406 size_t start[2], count[2];
12407
12408 /* Allocate... */
12409 ALLOC(help, double,
12410 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12411 ALLOC(help2, int,
12412 ctl->grid_nx * ctl->grid_ny * ctl->grid_nz);
12413
12414 /* Create file... */
12415 NC(nc_create(filename, NC_NETCDF4, &ncid));
12416
12417 /* Define dimensions... */
12418 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "time", 1, &dimid[0]));
12419 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "z", (size_t) ctl->grid_nz, &dimid[1]));
12420 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "lat", (size_t) ctl->grid_ny, &dimid[2]));
12421 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "lon", (size_t) ctl->grid_nx, &dimid[3]));
12422 NC(nc_def_dim(ncid, "dz", 1, &dimid[4]));
12423
12424 /* Define variables and their attributes... */
12425 NC_DEF_VAR("time", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &dimid[0], "time",
12426 "seconds since 2000-01-01 00:00:00 UTC", 0, 0);
12427 NC_DEF_VAR("z", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &dimid[1], "altitude", "km", 0, 0);
12428 NC_DEF_VAR("lat", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &dimid[2], "latitude", "degrees_north", 0,
12429 0);
12430 NC_DEF_VAR("lon", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &dimid[3], "longitude", "degrees_east", 0,
12431 0);
12432 NC_DEF_VAR("dz", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &dimid[1], "layer depth", "km", 0, 0);
12433 NC_DEF_VAR("area", NC_DOUBLE, 1, &dimid[2], "surface area", "km**2", 0, 0);
12434
12435 NC_DEF_VAR("cd", NC_FLOAT, 4, dimid, "column density", "kg m**-2",
12436 ctl->grid_nc_level, 0);
12437 NC_DEF_VAR("vmr_impl", NC_FLOAT, 4, dimid,
12438 "volume mixing ratio (implicit)", "ppv", ctl->grid_nc_level, 0);
12439 NC_DEF_VAR("np", NC_INT, 4, dimid, "number of particles", "1", 0, 0);
12440 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12441 sprintf(varname, "%s_mean", ctl->qnt_name[iq]);
12442 sprintf(longname, "%s (mean)", ctl->qnt_longname[iq]);
12443 NC_DEF_VAR(varname, NC_DOUBLE, 4, dimid, longname, ctl->qnt_unit[iq],
12444 ctl->grid_nc_level, ctl->grid_nc_quant[iq]);
12445 if (ctl->grid_stddev) {
12446 sprintf(varname, "%s_stddev", ctl->qnt_name[iq]);
12447 sprintf(longname, "%s (stddev)", ctl->qnt_longname[iq]);
12448 NC_DEF_VAR(varname, NC_DOUBLE, 4, dimid, longname, ctl->qnt_unit[iq],
12449 ctl->grid_nc_level, ctl->grid_nc_quant[iq]);
12450 }
12451 }
12452 /* End definitions... */
12453 NC(nc_enddef(ncid));
12454
12455 /* Write data... */
12456 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("time", &t, 0);
12457 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("lon", lon, 0);
12458 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("lat", lat, 0);
12459 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("z", z, 0);
12460 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("area", area, 0);
12461 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("dz", &dz, 0);
12462
12463 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12464 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++)
12465 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++)
12466 help[ARRAY_3D(iz, iy, ctl->grid_ny, ix, ctl->grid_nx)] =
12467 cd[ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz)];
12468 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("cd", help, 0);
12469
12470 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12471 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++)
12472 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++)
12473 help[ARRAY_3D(iz, iy, ctl->grid_ny, ix, ctl->grid_nx)] =
12474 vmr_impl[ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz)];
12475 NC_PUT_DOUBLE("vmr_impl", help, 0);
12476
12477 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12478 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++)
12479 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++)
12480 help2[ARRAY_3D(iz, iy, ctl->grid_ny, ix, ctl->grid_nx)] =
12481 np[ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz)];
12482 NC_PUT_INT("np", help2, 0);
12483
12484 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12485 sprintf(varname, "%s_mean", ctl->qnt_name[iq]);
12486 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12487 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++)
12488 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++)
12489 help[ARRAY_3D(iz, iy, ctl->grid_ny, ix, ctl->grid_nx)] =
12490 mean[iq][ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz)];
12491 NC_PUT_DOUBLE(varname, help, 0);
12492 }
12493
12494 if (ctl->grid_stddev)
12495 for (int iq = 0; iq < ctl->nq; iq++) {
12496 sprintf(varname, "%s_stddev", ctl->qnt_name[iq]);
12497 for (int ix = 0; ix < ctl->grid_nx; ix++)
12498 for (int iy = 0; iy < ctl->grid_ny; iy++)
12499 for (int iz = 0; iz < ctl->grid_nz; iz++)
12500 help[ARRAY_3D(iz, iy, ctl->grid_ny, ix, ctl->grid_nx)] =
12501 sigma[iq][ARRAY_3D(ix, iy, ctl->grid_ny, iz, ctl->grid_nz)];
12502 NC_PUT_DOUBLE(varname, help, 0);
12503 }
12504
12505 /* Close file... */
12506 NC(nc_close(ncid));
12507
12508 /* Free... */
12509 free(help);
12510 free(help2);
12511}
NC_PUT_INT
#define NC_PUT_INT(varname, ptr, hyperslab)
Write integer data to a NetCDF variable.
Definition: mptrac.h:1305

◆ write_met_bin()

void write_met_bin ( const char *  filename,
const ctl_t *  ctl,
met_t *  met 
)

Writes meteorological data in binary format to a specified file.

This function writes meteorological data from the met_t structure to a binary file. The data includes grid and surface data, as well as multi-level data such as temperature, velocity components, and atmospheric properties. The compression options for multi-level data (ZFP) are controlled via the ctl_t structure. The function supports multiple variables, such as surface pressure, temperature, wind components, and cloud properties.

Parameters
filenameA constant character pointer representing the name of the file to write the binary data to.
ctlA pointer to a ctl_t structure, which holds control parameters including the type of meteorological data, compression settings, and grid dimensions.
metA pointer to a met_t structure that contains the meteorological data to be written to the binary file.
Note
  • The function creates a new file to write the data. If the file cannot be created, an error is generated.
  • The type of meteorological data (ctl->met_type) and the version of the binary format are written at the beginning of the file.
  • Grid data such as longitude, latitude, pressure levels, and time are written to the file.
  • Surface data (e.g., pressure, temperature, wind components) are written using the write_met_bin_2d helper function.
  • Multi-level (3D) data such as geopotential height, temperature, and wind velocity are written using the write_met_bin_3d function with optional ZFP compression settings.
Author
Lars Hoffmann

Definition at line 12515 of file mptrac.c.

12519
12520 /* Create file... */
12521 FILE *out;
12522 if (!(out = fopen(filename, "w")))
12523 ERRMSG("Cannot create file!");
12524
12525 /* Write type of binary data... */
12526 FWRITE(&ctl->met_type, int,
12527 1,
12528 out);
12529
12530 /* Write version of binary data... */
12531 int version = 103;
12532 FWRITE(&version, int,
12533 1,
12534 out);
12535

12538 1,
12539 out);

12545 out);

12548 out);

12556 (size_t) met->np,

12583 write_met_bin_2d(out, met, met->o3c, "O3C");

12587 ctl->met_comp_prec[0], ctl->met_comp_tol[0]);

12589 ctl->met_comp_prec[1], ctl->met_comp_tol[1]);

12607 ctl->met_comp_prec[10], ctl->met_comp_tol[10]);

12609 ctl->met_comp_prec[11], ctl->met_comp_tol[11]);
12610 write_met_bin_3d(out, ctl, met, met->cc, "CC",
12611 ctl->met_comp_prec[12], ctl->met_comp_tol[12]);
12612 if (METVAR != 13)
12613 ERRMSG("Number of meteo variables doesn't match!");
12614
12615 /* Write final flag... */
12616 int final = 999;
12617 FWRITE(&final, int,
12618 1,
12619 out);
12620
12621 /* Close file... */
12622 fclose(out);
12623}
write_met_bin_3d
